head_text.subj: TWO STORY HIGH CORRIDORS THAT REEK OF HISTORY, (INT-DAY)

text: Young lawyer JAMEY COLLINS darts through the crowd, carry an accordion file under his arm like a football. Jamey elbows his way through a JAPANESE TOUR GROUP. Jamey trots up a marble staircase, two steps at a time

head_text.subj: JAMEY RUNS LIKE HELL DOWN A THIRD FLOOR CORRIDOR, FOOTSTE

text: making a racket... Jamey rushes toward a door marked "JUDGE TATE." RAISED VOICES from inside Judge Tate's chambers:
This construction site is causing mortal and irreparable harm to an unsuspecting public!
My client has one of the finest and most respected safety records in the business, Your Honor!
Jamey shoves open the door, REVEALING TWO LAWYERS (BACKS
(in conservative gray) and JOSEPH MILLER (in pinstripes).
One at a time. Mr. Miller?

Your Honor, since Rockwell Corp. began construction, the surrounding residential neighborhood has been enshrouded in a cloud of foul-smelling, germ-carrying, pestilent dust. My client is being forced to breathe known carcinogens daily! Other residents are coming forth on a daily basis to add their voices of outrage!

Your Honor, I submit there were no complaints until Counselor began knocking on doors, drumming up business. And the dust, which Counselor refers to, has appeared on only three occasions. Each time it has been examined and the results...
Behind his back, Andrew wiggles his fingers. Jamey stuffs a document into Andrew's hand.
Limestone. Messy, but innocuous.
Andrew submits the report to the Judge.
Innocuous?
Defined by Webster's as harmless.

I know what it means. Your Honor, imagine how the children in this neighborhood have been made to feel. The pounding of construction ringing in their ears as this skyscraper, a tribute to mankind's greed, grows daily, casting an ominous shadow over their lives, filling them with dread even as they are surrounded in a black, toxic fog, blocking out the sun while poisoning their lungs! And Counselor calls it harmless?!
His back turned momentarily to the JUDGE, Andrew mouths t Jamey: "Not bad." But he whips around, serious again:

Your Honor, Counselor is attempting to portray my client as a hideous manifestation of evil and corruption. But nothing could be further from the truth. Rockwell has generously contributed ten thousand dollars to this neighborhood's schools, clinics and youth centers! Granting a restraining order on the construction site will throw hundreds of Philadelphians out of work, and will lend validation to this contemptible and groundless nuisance suit, which speaks directly to the kind of greed and treachery that today is threatening the very fabric of our society.
Judge Tate looks skeptically at both lawyers.
Let's not go off the deep end, gentlemen. I thought we were talking about some dust.

You.

Right. (into phone) Miller.
The ELEVATOR OPENS: Andrew breezes past the MAN ON CRUTCHES, saying to Joe:
Client of yours?

head_text.subj: ANDREW EKERGES FROM CITY HALL, ONTO DILWORTH PLAZA BUSTLI

text: ... DARTS into the street, hailing a cab.

head_text.subj: THE CAB PULLS UP TO A BROWNSTONE ON A RESIDENTIAL STREET,

text: Andrew hopping out, stuffing papers into his briefcase (EXT./DAY) ... RUSHING to the door marked "Dr. Roberta Gillman, Internal Medicine." Coming out is a YOUNG ASIAN MAN with a cotton ball taped the inside of his elbow.

(MOSTLY YOUNG MEN) in a cheerful room... some, like a UPS DELIVERY MAN, are attached to IV's, some sit with arms extended, waiting to be hooked to an IV by TYRONE, a BLAC PHYSICIAN'S AID. CAMERA FINDS ANDREW sitting quietly, with an IV drip runn into his arm. Andrew is wearing a Walkman, the source of the CLASSICAL MUSIC, and he's reading a legal brief. Most of the people in the room look SICKER than Andrew. DIALOGUE CAN BE HEARD under the CLASSICAL MUSIC (although MUSIC dominates the SOUNDTRACK).
(slapping a thin PATIENT'S wrist) Gonna have to start looking for veins in your feet, sweetheart.
DR. ROBERTA GILLMAN, passes through, speaking to Andrew:
Andy. Can you stop at my office on your way out?
Sure.

Andrew is distracted by A HISPANIC MAN across the room, rolling up his sleeve for an IV -- his bare arms, hands, face and neck are marked with PURPLE BLOTCHES. Andrew closes his eyes, concentrating for a moment on the CLASSICAL MUSIC... then goes back to work.

head_text.subj: ANDREW HURRIES OUT OF THE DOCTOR'S OFFICE, HAILING A CAB
ANDREW HOPS OUT OF THE CAB, IN FRONT OF AN IMPRESSIVE

text: skyscraper in downtown Philly, at the end of the work day (EXT./DAY) ... Andrew pushes through glass doors into the plush "Wheeler Building," pressing through the tide of WORKERS headed ho

head_text.subj: A BLACK PARALEGAL, ANTHEA BURTON, LEADS A YOUNG, BLACK LA

text: CLERK (in suit and tie) to the elevators, at the sedate, expensively appointed offices of Wyant Wheeler Hellerman Tetlow and Brown (INT./DAY) ...
... up to Tax, on fourteen, and get right back, I need you.
Andrew BLASTS out of the elevator, flashing Anthea a four star smile. They stride down the corridor together.
Just the dazzling paralegal I wanted to see.
(friendly) I know what that means, and the answer is no. I have a class tonight. Exploit someone else. And since you've asked ...
They pass a silver-haired partner, KENNETH KILLCOYNE.
Solid work on the Rockwell situation, Andy. Top-notch.
Thanks, Kenneth. (to Anthea) Your exam!
Thank you. 98. I gotta go...
Ninety-eight?! Ninety-eight!
Andrew reaches the secretaries' station. A cheerful secretary, SHELBY, shoves documents at him.
Conference call's up. They just started the roll call. Here's the settlement agreement, the red-lined copy's on your desk. Need me in there?
No. Great. Thanks, Shelby. (checking his watch) It's 6:30, go home.
Andrew passes a colleague on her way out, RACHEL SMILOW:
Rach.
I'm late, I have to pick up Amy from her afterschool but I want to talk to you about that Hansen thing.
Catch me later, I'll be here. And tell Amy, I love her painting, it's on my wall.
Andrew SAILS toward his office.

head_text.subj: ANDREW ENTERS HIS OFFICE, KICKING THE DOOR SHUT

text: ... DROPPING the documents on his desk, SCANNING them. ... ADMIRING a child's painting taped to the wall. ... PUNCHING into the speaker phone on his desk. The
... Karen Hargreave, representing Lloyd Management Corporation?
The
: Andrew, the OPERATOR, and HARGREAVE (a sharp, California lawyer.)
Present.
As the OPERATOR continues the roll call, the

and HARGREAVE is replaced by a SERIES OF LAWYERS in offices around the country, (MOSTLY WHITE MALE saying "Present" while in  Andrew's section of the screen... ... Andrew dials a number on another telephone line,
Andrew Beckett, representing Saunders International?
Andrew punches into the conference call
Present.
The
is now joined by SARAH BECKETT, a suburban, 60ish American MOM, in her backyard garden, answering a portable phone.
Hello?
Hi, Mom. It's me.
The LAWYERS are into the conference, in  their portions of the screen, (their VOICES HEARD underneath Andrew's conversation with his mother).
Andy! This is a nice surprise. How are you, hon?
I'm fine.
What's Dr. Gillman say?
Hold on, Mom. (punching into the conference call) There's no way my client will go along with that.
Who's this?
Andrew Beckett. Hi, Karen. I'm sorry I interrupted...
He punches out of the conference, back to his Mom (glanci over his shoulder to make sure the door is  shut ).
Gillman says I'm fine. My blood work is excellent. T-cells are up. Just a sec ... (conference call) Yes, I think that would alleviate most of our concerns. (back to Mom) My platelets look good too.
Are you on one of those conference calls? I hate when you put me on hold.

head_text.subj: THE MOON ABOVE THE WHEELER BUILDING LATE AT NIGHT, (EXT.)

text: One-thirty a.m.

head_text.subj: ANDREW AT WORK IN THE FIRM'S LIBRARY, (INT./NIGHT)

text: Andrew's fingers FLY across the keys of a notebook comput Needing a reference, he shoves his rolling chair away fro the computer... opens a reference book... grabs a carton Chinese food... (NOTE: The library may be equipped with a computer terminal which Andrew uses for reference, rather than a book.) Andrew eats sauteed string beans with chopsticks, finding relevant citation:
Ah hah! Yes! (chewing a string bean) Rentworth v. Pennsylvania... court of appeals affirms jury award of punitive damages for wrongful interference with prospective economic relations...
A SHADOW falls across Andrew. He IGNORES IT. ANGLE: TWO MEN IN SILHOUETTE. WALTER KENTON says:
Look at this fucking guy. He's an animal.
Andrew's hands DO NOT LEAVE the keyboard.
Walter.
The SECOND MAN steps forward, a silhouette becoming visib This is BOB SEIDMAN. He and Kenton wear tuxedos.
Are we interrupting, Andy?
In a word, Bob...
Charles is right behind me.
ANOTHER SILHOUETTED FIGURE APPEARS. This image has a horror-film feeling to it. Andrew WHIPS AROUND to face them.
I was just about to take a break. Good evening, Charles.
CHARLES WHEELER, also in tuxedo, remains in shadow.
Andy? Could you step into my office for a sec? (deadpan) I feel like firing someone tonight.
Andrew throws an arm over Seidman's shoulder.
We're gonna miss you around here, Bob...

MAN, waiting for clearance from a SECURITY GUARD, on Andrew's dim and quiet floor, WATCHES AS... Seidman, Kenton and Andrew follow Charles Wheeler up a wi carpeted staircase. Wheeler finishes a story and everyone LAUGHS...

head_text.subj: A BOX OF CIGARS BEING HANDED AROUND, (INT./NIGHT)

text: Andy's expressed a keen interest in the Kronos Inc. situation, Charles. Is that correct, Andy?
The lawyers have gathered in Wheeler's spacious office, w its floor-to-ceiling view of the Philadelphia skyline.
The fate of the participants interests me, yes sir.

Wheeler, Kenton and Seidman proceed with the male ritual preparing cigars to be smoked: snipping the ends with a b clip, rolling them over their tongues to wet them, slidin cigars in and out of their rounded mouths. Andrew, holding a cigar but NOT preparing to light it, wa with a not completely concealed twinkle in his eye. Wheeler leans back in his chair, swirling a brandy snifte He exhales cigar smoke with a great deal of pleasure.
It's good to be King, hey Charles?
Kings are out of fashion. I'd rather be thought of as a benevolent tyrant. (prompting Andrew) It's an anti-trust action.

It is, and it isn't, Charles. Macrosystem's new software copies all the best-known elements of Kronos' spreadsheet program. If they're allowed to sell it, Kronos will get undersold right out of business. For me, the legal principle, involved is copyright infringement.
Bearing in mind that Bill Wright, the chairman of MacroSystems, is a close, personal friend of mine... which side of this mess would
you desire to be on, Andy? And don't allow my very tight, personal relationship with Bill to influence your answer in any way.
Andrew knows this is a test. And he loves it.
Sorry, Charles, but...
Andrew is distracted -- BY A LIGHT FALLING ACROSS HIS FAC
I'd like to see Kronos win.
Walter Kenton has shifted a lamp, so that its LIGHT FALLS
a faint purple blotch about the size of a quarter, much like the blotches we sa on the HISPANIC PATIENT in Andrew's doctor's office.
Why, Beckett?
Because they deserve to, Walter.
Andrew lifts his hand, finding that his hair has been pus back, revealing the blotch. He stands, nonchalantly running a hand through his hair t cover the blotch.

If MacroSystems wins, an energetic, young company will be destroyed, five thousand Americans will be out of work. Moreover, the laws of copyright and anti-trust were enacted to prevent exactly the kind of bullshit Macrosystems is trying to pull.
Andy, do you know who reps Kronos Inc.?
Bailey, Brackman.

Get with the program, Andy. As of this evening, about 8:05 this evening, right after the soup course... Kronos Incorporated is represented by Wyant Wheeler Hellerman Tetlow and Brown. Or, more specifically, senior associate Andrew Beckett.
A moment before it sinks in, then: Andrew clenches his fi in a victory salute.
Yes!
You'll have to get right on it, Andy, we're up against the statute of limitations.
An ASSOCIATE LAWYER in shirtsleeves taps on the office do
Tokyo on four, Bob.
Great. Excuse me, fellas. (picking up a phone, speaking Japanese) Connichiwa. Itsumo osewa ni nari mashita. Arigato gozaimasu.
Andrew offers his hand to Walter Kenton.
Thanks, Walter.
What's that on your forehead, pal?
Whacked with a racquetball. (taking Wheeler's hand) I appreciate your faith in my abilities.
Faith, Andy, is the belief in something for which we have no evidence. It doesn't apply to this situation. (slapping his shoulder) Go home. I mean, get back to work.
Andrew and Wheeler are eye-to-eye, an intimate moment.
(warmly, softly) Thanks, Charles.
(with a father's affection) No sweat, buddy.
Smiling, Andrew exits the office. CLOSE ON WALTER KENTON, THINKING...

text: away from Wheeler's office (INT./NIGHT), then... ... DOING a JOYFUL END ZONE DANCE, running in place the w football players do when then score a touch down, saying "Yes! Yes! Yes!" to himself, soundlessly. The SOUND OF CLANGING METAL interrupts Andrew: HELENA, a maintenance worker is emptying a trash can. She's seen hi little dance and starts to laugh. Smiling, Andrew puts the unlit cigar into his mouth, WINK at Helena and says:
(in a funny, kind of medieval way) It's good to be King.
Ten days later.

head_text.subj: ANDREW'S FACE MARKED WITH FOUR BLOTCHES

text: Andrew's loft -- INT./DAY)  It's a mirror image.  The BLOTCHES vary from the size of a dime, to the size of a half-dollar. He looks awful. A YOUNG, BLACK WOMAN'S FINGER applies makeup to Andrew's face, trying to cover the blotches. This is his friend CHANDRA.
You want to apply the foundation as evenly as you can, Andy. You don't want to look like you've thrown it on with a spoon.
Uh huh.

CAMERA PULLS BACK REVEALING Andrew sitting at a table in loft, a towel around his neck, protecting his shirt from Chandra applies the makeup gently, supervised by another named ALAN. (Andrew's loft has been turned into a lawyer' command post: stacks of books, documents, etc.). A third BRUNO, sits in the corner, flipping through channels on t
Okay. You try.
Andrew tries applying makeup to his face.
Chandra? Don't you think this color's a little... orange for me?
Tahitian Bronze works best on lesions.
Think of it as the "I just back from Aruba" look.
IN THE BACKGROUND: Andrew's fax machine receives a fax in Andrew's "work area": desk, personal computer, etc.).
I got it.
Bruno removes the fax from the machine, walking it over t Andrew, handing Andrew the fax, while munching an apple.

(giving the fax a quick scan) Thanks, Bruno. (to Alan and Chandra) I've been out of the office four days. I don't want them to think I've been to the beach. (searching for something) Okay. Check this out.
Andrew puts on a pair of big glasses with tortoise shell frames, meant to help conceal the blotches.
Hides everything, right? What do you think?
You know who you look like, Andy? That actor, in that movie. Not the one where he was autistic, the one where he dressed up like a lady on a soap opera...
Dustin Hoffman.
(horrified) Tootsie!
Right.
You want to try Light Egyptian?
Suddenly, Andrew winces, gripping his gut.
What?
(clearly in pain) Excuse me a sec...
Andrew starts out of the room -- suddenly HAVING TO RUN.
Just like my cousin Fredo.
CAMERA HOLDS ON Chandra, Alan and Bruno. SOUND OF BATHROO slamming shut. Bruno saunters across the room and knocks on the bathroom door.
You okay, Andy?
Andrew rests his head against the wall, sweat covering hi face. A storm of fire has passed through him, and he's ho it's over for now.
I think I need to go to the hospital.

head_text.subj: MIGUEL ALVAREZ RUNS URGENTLY DOWN SPRUCE STREET, DODGING

text: traffic as he crosses Eleventh Street, toward Jefferson Hospital (EXT./DAY). He hustles up the ramp toward the Emergency Entrance...

head_text.subj: MIGUEL SHOVES THROUGH GLASS DOORS, INTO THE BUSTLING

text: Emergency Room (INT./DAY), FINDING  ANDREW sitting on a gurney, holding a cotton ball against his arm, where blood has been drawn, wearing a blanket ov his shoulders, fighting chills. Chandra and Bruno are waiting with Andrew. They exchange quick hugs with Miguel and Andrew, ad libbing greetings a goodbyes.
Thanks, you guys.
Yeah. Thanks, guys.
Miguel puts his arms around Andrew.
Gillman's out of her office today. I
told her to take a day off, and she did, can you believe it? Did you get someone to cover your class?
Miguel touches Andrew's face, checking for fever.
Don't worry about it. They took blood? A specimen?
Andrew holds an empty specimen cup.
Aren't you giving an exam?
I said, don't worry about it.
Miguel places a gentle kiss on Andrew's sweaty forehead.
You got a fever, baby.
Suddenly, the facade cracks and TEARS STING Andrew's eyes
I almost didn't make it to the bathroom, Miguel. I almost lost control right in front of everybody.
(holding him) So what? It's nothing to be ashamed of. You have nothing to be ashamed of, okay?
Andrew pulls himself together, brushing aside tears, in control of his emotions once more.
Wait, here's my guy... Hey!
Andrew catches the attention of a harried INTERN, whose surgeon's greens are covered with blood.
Mr. Beckett, I'm sorry...
About my blood work?
We're waiting...
Miguel opens a small notebook, making notes.
... meanwhile, I'd like to prepare you for a colonoscopy, so we can take a look inside.
Sounds delightful.
Why do you need to do this?
Who are you?
Who are you? Doctor... ?
This is my partner. We keep records of hospital visits. Nothing personal.
Dr. Klenstein. (to Andrew) It's not a pleasant procedure, but if the KS is causing the diarrhea, we ought to know right away.
It could be parasites, an infection...
A reaction to AZT...
That's possible, but.
He's not going through some painful procedure until we've cancelled out everything else.
I'm trying to help your "partner." You're not a member of his immediate family, I could have you removed from the ER.
(to the Intern) He's upset, he's sorry.
Don't apologize for me.

He's not sorry, okay, fine. (the diplomat) Why don't we see what we find out from the blood work? I'll work on getting a specimen, I'm sure hospital food could help in that direction. Maybe, by then, we'll hear from my doctor, and we'll go from there. Okay? Everybody happy?
Allright. I'll get on the lab about the blood work.
(to the Intern) I'm sorry.
The INTERN walks away. Andrew's BEEPER BEEPS.
That's the third time. I better call the office. (smiling at Niguel) Would you relax, please?
I am relaxed.
Andrew HOBBLES toward a pay phone, outside a VISITOR LOUN where weary relatives are watching TV. Andrew drops a quarter into the phone.
"If you or someone you know..."
ANDREW'S POV ON TELEVISION: Joe Miller on the screen, wit words "Negligence... Malpractice... Auto accidents"... an the background, PHOTOS of MAIMED, BURNED, INJURED CLIENTS
"... has been injured through the fault of others, you may be entitled to legal remedy...
Andrew LAUGHS. Then, his call is answered:
Shelby? It's me. Jamey's been beeping me, I... Okay, okay, calm down. Put Jamey on.

head_text.subj: FIRST YEAR ASSOCIATE JAMEY COLLINS, SITTING AT ANDREW'S D

text: (INT/DAY), GRABS THE PHONE when Andrew's intercom BUZZES.
(frantic) Andy?! This is a disaster! We can't find your revisions on the Kronos complaint!
Slow down, Jamey, for Christ's sake!
I went down to Word Processing to pick up the corrected copy, but
they said you haven't delivered the corrections. I told them you've been working on it at home, and...
Andrew forgets his physical pain, this is more important.
I brought it in last night, around midnight. It's in my computer.
What did you file it under?
Jamey puts his hands on Andrew's computer keyboard.
K-R-O-one.
Jamey types the file name.
Jamey, I don't have to mention, do I, that we're up against a statute of limitations on this complaint which runs out in... (checks his watch) Seventy-five minutes.
Jamey stares dumbfounded at the computer monitor.
It's not here, Andy.
Andrew closes his eyes. He can't believe this.
You go down to Word Processing and tell those motherfuckers they better come up with that complaint,
now! Or they are fucking dead ! You tell them that comes from me!
Andrew SLAMS the phone into its cradle. He pauses, takes a deep breath, and says to himself:
Every problem has a solution. Every problem... has... a... solution.
Calmer, Andrew returns to the gurney, putting on his shir
Every problem has a solution...
Miguel approaches with tea purchased at the canteen.
Why are you getting dressed?
You're not going to like this. Please try to smile...
Andrew puts his arms around Miguel.
Thanks for leaving school, and coming here, and... (pulling back, putting on his jacket) I will be back. An hour, tops.
You're going to the office?!
You're not smiling.
Andrew rushes toward the exit doors.
You're leaving the hospital? You're going into the office looking like that? Are you insane?
One hour!
Drew!
I promise!

head_text.subj: ANDREW RUSHES TO THE STREET, HAILING A CAB, (EXT./DAY)
ANDREW STEPS OUT OF THE TAXI IN FRONT OF THE WHEELER

text: Building, heading for the entrance (EXT./DAY) ... But he changes his mind, darting to the corner of the blo Andrew stops to buy a baseball cap from a VENDOR. He trots down an alley, past bags of garbage, entering th building through a garage door.

head_text.subj: FROM A HIGH FLOOR, ANDREW CAN BE SEEN CLIMBING THE STEPS

text: an emergency stairwell (INT./DAY) ... Andrew passes CAMERA, out of breath. He's wearing the bal PULLED TO HIS EYEBROWS to hide blotches on his forehead.

head_text.subj: ANDREW OPENS THE FIRE DOOR ON HIS FLOOR AT WYANT WHEELER,

text: the ball cap, baring the purple blotches. (INT./DAY) He walks quickly down the hall. Passing a COLLEAGUE, Andr pretends to scratch his face, attempting to hide the blot as nonchalantly as possible. He dashes past an office, ignoring Anthea.
Didn't expect to see you... ?
He ducks into his office.

head_text.subj: SECRETARY SHELBY AT ANDREW'S DESK, FRANTICALLY SEARCHING

text: through papers (INT./DAY) ... Startled when he sees Shelby, Andrew spins toward the wal
I'm looking through the files but...
Call the messenger service, have someone standing by... (she reaches for the phone)
Your phone.
Sure.
Andrew keeps his face averted, until she's out of the roo goes to his computer, the monitor already glowing.
Think. You brought the discs in, you transferred...
Rachel comes into his office.
I thought I was supposed to be covering for you. (blurts out) God, Andy, you look awful.
Fucking Word Processing lost my Kronos complaint. Which must be filed by fucking five o'clock! If it's late, there's no case... (the mantra) Every problem has a solution.
What can I do?
Get down to Word Processing. Help Jamey look.
She rushes out. Andrew begins shoving floppy discs into the slots on his computer, bringing up each disc's directory.
No.
He throws the disc to the floor. Shoves in another. Shoves in another, bending it in half.
No, goddammit!
He pulls open a file drawer, dumping legal briefs onto th floor, frantically spreading them around with his foot. Andrew THROWS a document across the room, takes a breath. He picks up the telephone.

Bob? Something's come up. With Kronos. I don't want to upset Charles, but... (letting down his guard) Oh, shit, Bob, the complaint's due in forty minutes and I can't find it. (suddenly) No, you don't have to come... (hanging up the phone) Great. Fucking great.
Andrew rubs his eyes, this is a nightmare. He switches off the overhead light. He slants the window blinds, filling the room with shadow Bob Seidman comes into the office, typically cheerful.
C'mon, Andy, you didn't lose anything...
Seidman is struck by the mess in the office, and Andrew's disheveled appearance.
Jesus.
I don't know what to do, Bob.
You'll never find it in the dark.
Seidman FLIPS ON the overhead light. Andrew flinches. Seidman approaches. Andrew gives up trying to hide the purple blotches, facing his mentor straight on.
What in God's name... ?
Bob...
What's wrong with your face?
What's wrong with my face? You want to know what's wrong with my face? I've got a skin condition. Next question, Bob? No more questions? Fine. Now can you help me find the complaint?
Allright. Calm down.
Sorry...
Seidman sits in front of Andy's computer.
What was the file name?
K-R-O-one.
Maybe you mistyped the name when you were saving it. We'll try combinations of those letters...
Seidman goes to work. Andrew leans over his shoulder.
You're right, I probably just misfiled...
Andy?
Walter Kenton is standing at Andrew's door. His demeanor casual. So casual it seems a little forced.
Some sort of problem?
Andrew has kept his face averted. But now he TURNS DIRECT TOWARD CAMERA, showing his face to Kenton.
Yeah, Walter. Yeah. Some sort of major problem.

head_text.subj: SOUND OF A BABY CRYING CROSSES THE CUT TO
A NEWBORN BEING LIFTED INTO A DOCTOR'S HANDS, (INT./DAY)

text: There she is, okay. You can relax now, Lisa.
LISA MILLER has just given birth to a baby girl. She collapses on her pillow, gasping for breath, moaning in pain, quietly crying a little.
One month later.
The NURSES and the (FEMALE) DOCTOR move professionally around the bed, doing their jobs. At Lisa's side, Joe fumbles with a camera while darting amazed looks back and forth between Lisa and the baby.
Oh my god... a girl... oh my god... Lisa... oh my god...
He's frantic.
You load the film... ? No, on this side... or this side? Don't move the baby!
Give me the camera, Joe.
Lisa pops the film into the camera, hands it back.
Thanks, hon. Oh my god...
With wildly trembling hands, Joe begins SNAPPING PHOTOS.
Oh my god... oh my god, look at her... oh my god...

head_text.subj: JOE, WALKING THE HOSPITAL CORRIDOR, STILL WEARING SURGEON

text: greens, SPEAKING INTO HIS PORTABLE PHONE (INT./DAY) ...

Go to Famous Fourth Street and buy a pound of Nova. No! She likes Scotch salmon better. Ah heck, get a pound of both! Get a dozen onion rolls. Get some bagels. Get a dozen. Get a bottle of champagne. Dom Peringon... A hundred bucks a bottle?! Better get a good California...
Passing a PATIENT IN TRACTION, ROLLING BY ON A GURNEY, Jo drops a business card into the PATIENT'S broken hand.

(to the PATIENT) Give me a call. (into the phone) Get everything over here as soon as you can, she's starved. No, not the baby! Lisa! ... Iris, listen: any calls I should know about? ... Uh huh... Uh huh... Beckett? Who's Andrew Beckett?
Turning a corner, Joe comes face to face with HIS RELATIV who charge at him joyfully:
Congratulations! How is Lisa?! When can we see the baby?!

head_text.subj: QUIET... JOE, LISA AND THEIR BABY CUDDLED TOGETHER IN

text: Lisa's hospital bed, surrounded by debris from a party, paper plates, empty champagne bottle (INT./NIGHT) ... The relatives have gone. It's late at night. Lisa holds the baby. Joe holds them both.

head_text.subj: AN INTERSECTION IN THE HEART OF OLD, DOWNTOWN PHILLY

text: movie palace (now a six-plex) across the street from the Peter Pan Coffee Shop, PHILADELPHIA WORKERS going about t business of the day (EXT./DAY) ...
One week later.
Above the Peter Pan Coffee Shop is a string of large windows, each of which is painted with a question:
In bigger letters, across several windows:
We hear JOE MILLER'S VOICE-OVER:
How big was this hole you fell into?

head_text.subj: A HALLWAY BULLETIN BOARD ANNOUNCING THE VARIOUS DEPARTMEN

text: "Macready and Shilts Legal Services" (INT./DAY), includin "Auto/DUI/Collisions with Deer... Product liability... Me malpractice... Pet bites..." The bulletin board stands at the entrance to a warehouse lawyers' cubicles formed by office dividers and plastic f PHONES JANGLING... INJURED CLIENTS LIMPING ABOUT...
And this hole was right in the middle of the street?

head_text.subj: JOE IS IN HIS OFFICE, A BOX OF CIGARS ON THE DESK WITH PI

text: bands announcing "It's a girl!" (INT./DAY). On the walls photos of INJURED CLIENTS (the same photos we saw in the background of Joe's TV commercial)... A FEMALE CLIENT (MRS. FINLEY) faces Joe, her arm in a sli
Right.
Why didn't you cross at the crosswalk?
Why should I?

head_text.subj: , SITTING ON A SOFA IN THE WAITING

text: area. Very little hair shows beneath a Phillies ballcap.. A MAN WEARING A NECKBRACE, sitting next to Andrew, RISES, MOVING to a seat opposite Andrew. From this new position MAN WITH THE NECKBRACE STARES at Andrew.

The PURPLE BLOTCHES on Andrew's face are beginning,to rec not as angry looking as before, thanks to chemo therapy. Andrew is dressed casually, in jeans and a softball jacke (from the Wyant Wheeler team) with "Andy" embroidered ove heart. Joe's assistant, IRIS, approaches.
Mr. Beckett?

Andrew rises, following Iris past office dividers, HARRIE SECRETARIES and overflowing file cabinets. Iris  cannot look at Andrew as she walks beside him. (Outside Joe's door is a sign: "Beware Mad Dog" with "Mad written by hand.)
In here.
Thank you.
at the photos while Joe wraps up...

(to the FEMALE CLIENT) Explain this to me like I'm a six year old, okay? The entire street is clear except for one small area under construction, with a huge hole that is clearly marked and blocked off, and you decide you
must cross the street at this spot. You fall into the hole and you want to sue the city for negligence? ...
Yeah. Do I have a case?

Of course you have a case! Now, I want you to go with my assistant, Iris, and fill out some forms. She'll tell you about our fee arrangement. (as they're leaving) Mrs. Finley? Any back pain since the accident? Dizziness? Nightmares?
Now that you mention it...
Tell Iris all about it. (leading her out) Take good care of Mrs. Finley, Iris. (to Andrew) Beckett, come in.
Joe offers his hand, getting a look at Andrew's face.
Jesus Christ, what happened to you?
I have AIDS.
Joe WITHDRAWS his hand, before it touches Andrew's.
Whoa-oh! (beat) Sorry, I...
It's okay. Can I sit down?
Uh, yeah.
Andrew hesitates. Joe doesn't sound sure.
Go ahead.
Andrew sits, Joe returns to his desk. (Joe finds himself acutely aware of where Andrew places his hands.)
(the cigars) New baby?
One week old.
Congratulations.
Little baby girl.
Kids are great.
Thanks, Beckett. I'm real excited about it. (glances at his watch) What can I do for you?
I was fired by Wyant Wheeler. I plan to bring a wrongful termination suit against Charles Wheeler and his partners.
You want to sue Wyant Wheeler Hellerman Tetlow and Brown?
Correct. I'm seeking representation.
Continue.
I misplaced an important complaint. That's their story. Want to hear mine?
How many lawyers did you go to, before you called me?
Nine.
Continue.

I was diagnosed with AIDS eight months ago. During a bout of pneumonia. I recovered quickly and was back at work in ten days. Since I was doing so well on the AZT, we decided against telling anyone about it.
We?
My lover and I.
Your... lover?
Miguel Alvarez. We've lived together for nine years.
Continue.
I dove back into work, everything was fine. Until the lesions started...

head_text.subj: TIGHT ON ANDREW WAUKING THROUGH THE LOBBY OF THE WHEELER

text: Building (INT./DAY). He's wearing MAKEUP, which sort of covers the blotches. (NOTE: PICTURE and ANDREW'S VOICE OV do NOT match up. This is no ordinary flashback) ...
First on my leg. Then my forearm, my back. Then... my face. For a short period, I avoided the office during the day, waiting for the chemo therapy to clear up the lesions...
But I never let anything slide. I made all my calls from home. I worked sixteen hour days on a complaint for a 350 million dollar copyright infringement suit.
But the day the complaint was due, it disappeared. Erased from my computer. I thought I was losing it, mentally...

head_text.subj: NOW HE SPEAKS DIRECTLY TO CAMERA

text: That can happen, it's called AIDS dementia when it gets into your brain. But miraculously, a copy of the complaint was located at the last minute, and we got it to court on time...

head_text.subj: GIVING HIM LOOKS, WHISPERING. ANTHEA BURTON NODS HELLO.

text: The next morning, I was called to the office for a meeting with the managing partners. Walking down that corridor was strange. Felt like everyone was staring.

head_text.subj: AND JOE WALKING AT ANDREW'S SIDE

text: Hell, they are staring. What's that shit on your face?
Makeup.
The partners were waiting for me in the main conference room.

head_text.subj: CAMERA TRACKS INTO THE CONFERENCE ROOM, GIVING US ANDREW'

text: POV as he enters the room where Wheeler, Kenton, Killcoyn Bob Seidman are waiting (INT./DAY) ...
Sit down, Andy.
Wheeler's secretary, LYDIA, takes notes.
Thanks for coming in.
Of course.
Bob Seidman CANNOT look directly at Andrew.
Andy. Before we begin, I'd just like to say: everyone in this room is your friend.
You're in trouble.
(NOTE: Joe IS SEEN IN HIS OFFICE, or LEANING AGAINST A WINDOW IN THE CONFERENCE ROOM whenever he speaks.)
I know that, Charles.
More than your friend. Family.
Big trouble.
Charles, I must apologize again, for the Kronos mishap. (smiling) It was a scary few minutes around here. Wow. But thank God, the complaint was found. And no damage was done.
This time. What about next time?
There won't be a next time, I guarantee it.
Andy. It seems that something has come over you, lately: A kind of... stupor, a fogginess, a lack of focus... Earth to Andy. Anybody home?
Helloooo...
That's right, Andy. The last four, five months you've seemed really out of it...
At least... different, somehow.
(keeping it positive) Perhaps... you're right. I've certainly been busy. With the Kronos complaint, a preliminary injunction hearing and the Saunders trial all falling at the same time...
Some people think you have an attitude problem, Beckett.
Really? Who thinks that, sir?
I do.
Wheeler seems very grave.
I had no idea there was a concern in that area. Hey: (a smile) I'll get to work on it right away.
NO ONE else smiles.
We've been talking it over, Andy. Your future that is... We feel that, because we respect you so much, we have to be honest with you.
Honesty is always best.
Do you really think so, Andy?
Yes, Bob, I do. (to the group) Excuse me? Am I being fired?
Let's put it this way, Andy: your place in the future of this firm is no longer secure.
In a word, yes.
We don't think it's fair to keep you here, where your future is limited. But we wish you luck, Andy, all the luck in the world.
Wheeler rises, wearing a friendly smile.
And I hate to rush you out of here, but...
But he's got lots of other people's lives to ruin...
... we've got a committee meeting.

Excuse me, Charles. With all due respect... this is... preposterous! It doesn't make any sense, it sounds as if we're talking about someone else. Pardon the lack of humility, but I've had the distinct impression I was kind of... one of the rising stars around here. And I feel that wasn't just my imagination. And I also think I deserve to know what's really going on here, Charles.
Oh, you're right, Beckett, you don't have an attitude problem.
Take it easy, Walter.
If you'd lost confidence in me, why did you give me the Kronos suit?
I hoped the challenge would improve your performance. You could say it was a carrot.
A carrot?!
I buy that.
As in, the vegetable?

(suddenly emotional) Andy, you nearly blew the case, for God's sake! That alone is inexcusable. It would have been catastrophic for us. Put yourself in our shoes, Andy. There's no coming back from an error like that, regardless of who you are! (softer) I'm sorry, Andy.
Andrew FREEZES -- the full nature of this situation hitti home. He looks each of the PARTNERS in the eye...
Uh huh... Okay... I see...
... at last LOOKING DIRECTLY AT Wheeler's secretary Lydia whose pen is poised above her notebook, waiting for someo to say something. Wheeler breaks the silence.
Good luck, Andy.
Wheeler, Kenton, Killcoyne, Seidman and Lydia file out. Andrew doesn't move. A SECURITY GUARD enters the room.
Who are you?
I'm here to escort you to your office so you can organize your belongings.

head_text.subj: CAMERA PULLS BACK FROM ANDREW, WE'RE IN JOE'S OFFICE

text: Okay. Explain to me like I'm a two year old, because there's an element to this I can't get through my thick head: Didn't you have an obligation to inform your employer you had this dreaded, deadly, infectious disease?
Andrew removes his ballcap -- his hair is cut short, to disguise the effects of chemo.
The law says people with disabilities cannot be terminated, so long as they can perform the duties required by their position...

Okay, okay... They discover you have this horrible, disgusting, terminal illness, and they panic, for any number of perfectly valid reasons. They're frightened for themselves, their families... Maybe it's the homo angle. Maybe they don't want to rub elbows with someone who's just popped out of the closet with a terminal case of acne. And how do they explain your status to the client for Chrissake?
Joe, from the day I arrived to the day they fired me, I performed consistently, thoroughly and with absolute excellence. And if they hadn't fired me, that's what I'd be doing today.
Okay... They want you out. It's against the law to fire you for having AIDS, so they make you look like a fuck up. Which leads us to the mysterious, lost file.
They sabotaged me.
I knew you were going to say that. I don't buy it, and I don't see a case.
Look. I know I have a case. If you don't want to take it for personal reasons...
Correct. I don't.
Andrew rises, thoroughly business-like.
Thanks for your time.
Beckett? I'm sorry about... what's happened to you. It's a fucking kick in the head.
(a smile) Don't send flowers, Joe. I'm not dead yet.
Andrew exits.
(still uncomfortable, as Andrew's leaving) Have a nice day.
Andrew nods, passing one of Joe's colleagues, a hustler named FILKO, who STARES SHAMELESSLY. Joe approaches Iris's desk.
Find out if Armbruster can see me this afternoon.
(still staring) What the hell's wrong with him?
(EXT./DAY). CLOSE ON ANDREW, standing there as an endless people passes by. He watches them go, thinking...

head_text.subj: A SUBURBAN DOCTOR'S OFFICE IN A MIDDLE-CLASS NEIGHBORHOOD

text: You had contact with someone who has AIDS, and you're worried.

head_text.subj: A DOCTOR UNRAVELLING A BLOOD PRESSURE GAUGE, (INT./DAY)

text: I'm not worried. What are you doing?
Joe sits in his shirtsleeves on the examining table.
Checking your blood pressure, relax.
The DOCTOR wraps the blood pressure unit around Joe's arm
I didn't have contact. What do you consider "contact?" We were sitting in the same room, three, four feet... What if you shake hands? Wait. I know the answer. Only sex, or sharing needles.
I know that. We didn't shake hands, anyway.
Dr. Armbruster squeezes the blood pressure pump,
The HIV virus can only be transmitted through the exchange of bodily fluids, namely blood and semen.
Right.
Joe begins rolling down his sleeve.
Leave that.

Yeah, but Doc, isn't it true they keep finding out new things about this disease? So you tell me, today, there's no danger, and I go home, and I hold my baby, and six months from now I hear on the news: "whoops! We were wrong.' You
can carry it on your clothes, your skin, and now I've got to worry about my kid. What are you doing?
Dr. Armbruster has been preparing a syringe.
We're going to draw blood.
Why are we going to do that?
Joe. I don't care a whit about your private life.
You want to give me an AIDS
test
Joe HOPS off the table.
The guy sat in my office! You can't get AIDS that way, right?
Right.
It doesn't travel through the air, by breathing, or touching, right?
Not by touching, or shaking hands, or hugging, using the same toilet... Even kissing someone with AIDS is safe. But it there's something in your past you're worried about...
Thanks, Doc, but I don't need an AIDS test. Are you crazy? But thanks for the information. Really.
Joe throws on his jacket, opens the door... then TURNS BA
In my past?
IV drug use.
Joe shakes his head.
A homosexual encounter.
Get real.
Unprotected sex with a prostitute.
(thinking it over) Uh.... No. Not really.
Or unprotected sex with someone you didn't know very well, any time during the last twelve years.
Joe returns to the examining table, and rolls up his slee
You have a problem with gays, Joe.

head_text.subj: JOB CRADLES HIS BABY AGAINST HIS CHEST, (INT./NIGHT)

text: Not especially.
Lisa eats standing up, at the stove, while Joe walks the BABY in their modern kitchen.
How many gays do you know?
How many do you know?
Lots.
Who?

Karen Berman. Aunt Teresa. My cousin Tommy who lives in Rochester. Eddie Meyers from the office. Joe Cantwell, he's one of the partners. His lover, Greg. Stanley, the guy who's putting in our kitchen cabinets.
For a moment, Joe is struck dumb. Then he says:
Your Aunt Teresa is gay? That beautiful, sensuous woman is a...
lesbian
Duh...
Since when?
Probably since she was born.
Allright. I admit it: I'm prejudiced. I don't want to work with a homosexual. You got me.
Okay, Joe...

I mean, two guys, doing the horizontal thing? I don't get it. Don't they get confused? "Is that mine? I thought it was yours." Hey, call me old fashioned, call me conservative... I think maybe you have to be a man to get just how nauseating the whole basic idea really is.
Fine, Joe.
And the way they work out, pumping up, so they can be macho and faggot at the same time... I can't
stand that shit. Now I'm being totally honest with you.
That's perfectly clear.
Would you take a client if you were constantly thinking: "I hope this guy doesn't touch me. I don't even want him to
breathe on me?"

head_text.subj: THE STREETS OF PHILLY ARE DUSTED WITH SNOW, STORE WINDOWS

text: decorated for Christmas. Joe steps out of the Famous 4th St. Deli, with a package (EXT./DAY) ...
Two weeks later.

head_text.subj: JOE SITS AT A TABLE IN THE PUBLIC LAW LIBRARY, SURROUNDED

text: books and legal pads, hard at work. He's eating a pastram sandwich which he hides behind a reference book when a LI saunters by (INT./DAY) ... A CHAIR SQUEAKS and Joe LOOKS UP TO SEE: Andrew taking a seat across the room ( the blotches have been reduced by chemo, but he's struggling with a cold ). Andrew removes notepads and pens from his briefcase. He takes ou package of tissues, blowing his nose.
(under his breath) Shit...
Joe slides to the far end of his table, stacking seven or eight HUGE REFERENCE BOOKS in front of him.
Andrew opens a book, taking notes. Rubs his eyes. Writes something. Sneezes. A LIBRARIAN delivers a book to Andrew.
This is the supplement. You're right, there is a section on... (lowers her voice) ... HIV related discrimination.
Thank you.
Andrew takes the book from her -- but she remains.
We have a private research room available.
I'm fine, thanks.
Andrew BLOWS HIS NOSE. Now other PATRONS are watching.
Wouldn't you be more comfortable in a research room?
(pleasantly) No. But would it make you more comfortable?
Whatever, sir.

The LIBRARIAN turns away, shrugging to a PATRON, indicati she's done all she can do. As Joe continues to watch: one of Andrew's NEIGHBORS pick up his books and moves away. Joe rises, gliding down an aisle of books, keeping one ey on Andrew, who concentrates on his work. Joe approaches, nonchalantly, as if he just  happens to be sauntering by. Suddenly he "notices" Andrew.
Oh, Beckett. How's it goin'?
Fine.
Andrew goes back to his work.
Who'd you get?
What?
Find a lawyer?
I'm a lawyer. How's your baby?
Huh? Oh. Great. She's great.
What's her name?
Rayisha.
Rayisha. Very nice.
Andrew focuses on his work. Joe steps away. Joe comes back.
How did they find out?
(a second, then:) One of the partners spotted a lesion on my forehead.
Nearby, a CHINESE PROFESSOR looks up, startled, when she hears the word "lesion."
Uh huh...
Andrew concentrates on his work once more.
How do you get from one lawyer spotting a lesion, which could have been a bruise, to the partners deducing you had AIDS and basing a decision to terminate you on that conclusion?
The CHINESE PROFESSOR moves away.
Good point.
Andrew removes a legal pad with "KENTON" written in big letters across the top, and lots of notes underneath.

The partner who spotted the lesion, Walter Kenton, used to work for Benton, Myers, in D.C. There's a paralegal there, Maria Torres. She's had lesions on and off for three years. She says it was common knowledge around the office that her lesions were caused by AIDS.
They didn't fire her?
No. They didn't fire her.
Andrew goes back to his work. Joe stands there.
So Kenton connected the... lesion,

and whatever suspicions he had about your personal life... to this woman, Maria... and blew the whistle on you. Suddenly you're losing files, and it's time to let you go. But, up to this point, you've been their Golden Boy, their rising star... Their behavior is... inconsistent.
Thank you.
Andrew goes back to work.
There is no relevant precedent.
(not looking up) Arline decision. Supreme Court.
Arline?
Andrew SHOVES the legal book toward Joe.

with one blotch ) on the book's white pages. The book is still  facing Andrew. If Joe wants to read it, he'll have to turn it around. Joe looks at Andrew's hands. A MOMENT. Joe turns the book around, begins to read:
"The Federal Vocational Rehabilitation Act of 1973 prohibits discrimination..."
"... against otherwise qualified handicapped persons who are able to perform the duties required by their employment..."

head_text.subj: CAMERA GOES HIGHER, LOOKING DOWN ON THE ROWS OF BOOKS AND

text: "Although the ruling did not address the specific issue of HIV and AIDS discrimination..."
Andrew and Joe face each other at their table, but NO ONE ELSE remains at that tab or at the table next to it...
"Subsequent decisions have held that AIDS is protected as a handicap under law, not only because of the physical limitations it imposes..."
Joe pacing, Andrew reading. Their section of the library is COMPLETELY EMPTY but for Andrew and Joe.
"But because the prejudice surrounding AIDS exacts a social death which precedes the actual, physical one..."
Andrew and Joe sit on the same side of the table, reading the same book.
"This is the essence of discrimination: formulating opinions about others not based on their individual merits but, rather, on their membership in a group with assumed characteristics...
The library is QUIET. Andrew SNEEZES. Joe scoots his chair away from Andrew by eight inches.

head_text.subj: DISCO MUSIC RISES ACCOMPANIED BY THE SOUNDS OF GRUNTING,
HEAVY BREATHING AND SLAPPING FLESH AS WE...

text: INTO EACH OTHER, sounds of GRUNTS, skin SLAPPING against skin (INT./NIGHT) ... ... Hand SLAPPING a butt under satin shorts ... Sweaty armpits... the ROAR OF A CROWD... ... BASKETBALL PLAYERS embracing, twirling each other aro fiving... WIDE ANGLE REVEALS: A basketball game in progress, Sixers versus the Celtics in Philly's Spectrum Arena.
ROBERT PARISH going for a lay-up...
Watch this guy! Nail him! Ouch!

Charles Wheeler, Walter Kenton, Kenneth Killcoyne, Bob Se and SEVERAL LAWYERS and SPOUSES watch the game from a plu private box, complete with TV, bar, snack table. The lawy Ralph Lauren polos, chinos and ball caps. The place reeks cigar smoke. Walter Kenton has a twentyfive year old WIFE Charles Wheeler's nine year old GRANDSON sits nearby. Wheeler turns the GRANDSON'S ballcap around, smiling lovingly at the boy. JUST BEYOND WHEELER: The door to the box is opened by a S GUARD and a well-dressed, charismatic MAN looks in.
(spotting him) Julius!
Dr. J.!
Gentlemen... Ladies...
JULIUS ERVING enters, greeted by the LAWYERS.
How's it goin', Doctor?/This is an honor!/etc ...
The door is opened again, by the SECURITY GUARD, REVEALIN Joe Miller (in jeans and basketball jacket) and a MARSHAL
Excuse me. Charles Wheeler?
Wheeler turns. Joe SLAPS a document into Wheeler's hand.
Summons. For you.
NOW the box is QUIET.
Say. What's up, Chuck?

head_text.subj: THE BRIGHTLY LIT, RESTRICTED, INNER CORRIDOR OF SPECTRUM

text: Stadium (INT./NIGHT) where Wheeler walks beside Bob Seidm with Walter Kenton and Kenneth Killcoyne just behind. SOU OF THE GAME STILL IN PROGRESS can be heard, but FAR AWAY. Occasionally the lawyers are passed by FOOD SERVICE or LA SERVICE EMPLOYEES...
... interview every employee, support staff, associates, partners. Did

any of them know Andy was sick? How did they know? Did he tell them? Did they notice something was wrong with his appearance? None of this information got to the managing partners. We know that. Make sure everyone else does too... And Beckett: I want to know everything about his personal life. Did he frequent those pathetic bars on Camac Street?
Jesus.
(ignoring Seidman) What about other homosexual facilities, whatever they are?
Charles...
What deviant groups or organizations did he secretly belong to? (with irritation) What is it, Bob?!
Let's settle with Andy and put this whole tragic mess behind us.
They arrive at a quiet, semi-private cul de sac.
Andrew brought AIDS into our offices, into our men's room. He brought AIDS to our annual goddamn family picnic.
We ought to be suing him.
For Christ's sake, where's your compassion?
Compassion? Andy sucks cocks, Bob. He takes it up the ass. He's a pervert.
Only Seidman shows any kind of REACTION.
That's kind of... extreme, Walt. Andy's private life is none of our business.
Bob. You're trying my patience. Andrew Beckett is making his private life our business. We gave him Kronos. Did he say, "I'm sick. I might not be able to see this through?"
He was doing a great job.
Bob. I must ask you to shut the fuck up. Did Andrew Beckett say "I might not be able to serve our clients to the
best of my ability
He said nothing. And now, Andrew Beckett proposes to haul me into a court of law, to sling accusations at me, in full view of the entire, Philadelphia, judicial establishment. My God.
Beckett doesn't want to go to court, he's hoping for a quick tasty settlement.
A jury might decide that Andy has a case.
Wait a minute. The man was fired for incompetence, not because he has AIDS. You didn't know he was sick, did you, Bob?
Holy Shit. Did you, Bob?
(after a moment) No. Not really.
Wheeler walks away, followed by Kenton and Killcoyne. Bob Seidman stands alone in this dark place.

head_text.subj: ON A WORK DAY AS WE CUT TO
EXTERIOR, JOE'S OFFICE BUILDING, ON A THURSDAY MORNING.

text: JOB'S COLLEAGUE, FILKO, LOOKING DIRECTLY INTO CAMERA (in Joe's offices, INT./DAY):
Charles Fucking Wyant Wheeler?!
Joe sweeps by, just arriving for work.
Morning, Filko.
Filko keeps pace with Joe down the corridor. ANOTHER COLLEAGUE calls out from an office as Joe passes:
Hey, it's the local chapter of the ACLU!
You're a Republican, Joe! You belong to the NRA!
How many toilet stalls are there in the women's restroom on this floor, Filko?
How many... what?!
Filko follows Joe into Joe's office.
Two. How many toilet stalls are there in the
men's room? Two, plus four urinals. How many wheelchair accessible toilets in
either of those restrooms? Zero. In this entire building? Zero. Get the picture, Filko?
Discrimination ! You find yourself a female, paraplegic, legal assistant who is qualified to work here, except she can't take a leak... and you've got yourself a sex discrimination suit
and a handicapped discrimination suit. Not handicapped. What do you call someone who can't use a normal restroom? "Gastro-intestinally challenged!"
Behind Joe, out a large window: PAINTERS on a scaffold. Iris comes into the office and says:
Wyant Wheeler's asking for a postponement on the prelim, Joe.
Joe is dialing the phone.

Low-life, sleazy scumbags. Of course they want a postponement, I've got a client with a terminal disease. They're going to drag their heels every step of the way, the rotten bastards. (tapping on the window, to the
Is that spelled right?

head_text.subj: EXTERIOR, JOE'S OFFICE BUILDING, WHERE PAINTERS ARE ADDIN

text: question to the line of windows (DAY):

head_text.subj: D I S C R I M I N A T E D A G A I N S T

text: Hey, Beckett. This is Miller.

head_text.subj: JOE'S VOICE COMES THROUGH, ON THE ANSWERING MACHINE IN

text: Andrew and Miguel's loft (INT./DAY)
I just wanted to tell you...
CAMERA DRIFTS THROUGH the loft, finding Andrew in the roo solarium, sitting crosslegged in front of a candle.
... we're trying to set a date for the prelim. Hang in there.
Andrew's eyes are closed. Next to him rests a tape player WOMAN'S VOICE IS HEARD, accompanied by NEW AGE MUSIC:
I can heal myself.
I can heal myself.
I can heal myself.
I can heal myself.
each other in bed (INT./NIGHT) ...
I was coming out of the gym today, and I ran into Jimmy. Do you know what he asked me? "What's it like knowing your boyfriend's going to die?"
Jerk... What did you say?
I said, "Everyone's going to die, Jimmy. But Drew's not going to die of AIDS. There's a cure around the corner, and he plans to be around to take advantage of it."
Miguel strokes Andrew's hair.
You got that right, Mikey... (beat) You still believe that, don't you?

Yes. I think it will be a simple solution. They'll put it in a syringe, inject it into your bloodstream. It'll neutralize the virus. It'll revitalize the immune system, and people with AIDS will become healthy again.

head_text.subj: HOLD ON MIGUEL AND ANDREW, ON THIS QUIET MOMENT.

text: Three months later.

head_text.subj: A LONG CORRIDOR IN A CITY COURT BUILDING

text: corridor TWO FIGURES WALK TOWARD CAMERA (INT./DAY) ... The figures APPROACHING CAMERA are Andrew and Joe, steppi into and out of sunlight falling through tall windows.
Pre-trial settlement conference.
A PHALANX OF LAWYERS -- at least ten -- APPROACHING CAMER bulwark of white shirts and dark ties.
Andrew's hair is short, but growing back, the blotches ha receded,his weight is up. He's in a stage of recovery.
Charles Wheeler (seeming ironic) and Walter Kenton (he's pissed) lead the battalion. Behind them, walk young lawyers BELINDA CONINE and JEROME GREEN. Belinda is white, Jerome is black.

A JUDGE'S CHAMBERS, with couches, soft chairs scattered i loose circle, like a casual living room. Joe and Andrew whisper to each other. The Wyant Wheeler t takes up several chairs. Belinda Conine and Jerome Green next to Wheeler and Kenton. Some of their ASSISTANTS stan Wheeler is looking across the room at... Andrew, who catches Wheeler's stare.
You're looking better, Andy. How do you feel?
SILENCE. Everyone watches Andrew for his reaction.
Fine, thanks, Charles.
JUDGE LUCAS GARNETT enters his chambers (not wearing a Judge's robe). He shakes hands with Wheeler and Kenton.
Charles, Walter...
Congratulations on the new grandson.
Thank you. We're very happy.
The Judge brushes by Joe and Andrew without a word. The r becomes SILENT as the Judge takes a seat.
Attorney for the plaintiff?
Joseph Miller, Your Honor. Macready and Shilts Legal Services.
I've seen your television commercials. "If you or anyone you know has been injured through the fault of others... It should say, "through the
negligence of others."
I'll take that under consideration, Your Honor.
On behalf of the defendants?
Belinda Conine. Of Petersen, Lehigh, Monroe and Smith.
And Jerome Green.
And a WASPISH lawyer wearing round glasses:
Dexter Smith.
A white-haired lawyer next to Belinda:
Ralph Petersen.
(to Joe) You're outnumbered four to one. (to the others) Whom do I address? I can't talk to four lawyers at once.
I'm chief litigator, Your Honor.

Fine. I've asked the litigants to be present for this conference, in the hope we can settle this matter today, among ourselves... There is nothing I hate more, than to see lawyers suing each other. If you look at the opinion polls, when Mr. John Q. Citizen is asked to rank professions according to the respect he holds for them... Where are the lawyers? Somewhere below personal fitness trainers and only slightly above child pornographers. If we keep suing each other, if we fail to settle the smallest difference among ourselves with mutual respect, if we continue to scrap like bucks in heat, we'll fall lower on that list. And when people lose respect for lawyers, they lose respect for the law. And when this society loses all respect for the law, we'll be murdered in our beds, my friends, our cherished institutions will be burned to the ground and our children and our grandchildren will live like savages.
If it please Your Honor, we
hope to settle this matter.
By God you
will settle it! If you force this case to trial, young man, you'll regret it for the rest of your natural-born days... Now, Joseph. What would you require to settle this matter today?
Reinstatement at full salary. Back pay covering the period of unemployment and...
Hold it, Joe. (to Wheeler) He wants to come back to work, Chuck.
That's impossible, Your Honor.
That's impossible, Joe.
If it please Your Honor, we're prepared to offer a cash settlement of twenty-five thousand dollars.
Your generosity overwhelms me, Belinda, considering my client was earning over a hundred thou when he was terminated almost six months ago.
Give me a break, Joe. Let's cut through these false attitudes. Give them a figure. How much do you want?
I
want to go back to work, Your Honor.
You're here at my indulgence, young man. I'm waiting for a figure, Joe.
Andrew and Joe confer with each other.

Based on what my client would have earned over the next three years, including benefits and projected raises, and the extraordinary cost of medical care for someone with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome... We would settle today for the very fair amount of one million five hundred thousand dollars.
Very good, Joe. Now, Belinda, I've got a figure over here, of one million, five. I...
Andrew WHISPERS to Joe, who interrupts the Judge:
One more thing, Your Honor...
(jumping in) Any settlement agreement
must include, and this is critical, a letter of exoneration, making clear my termination had nothing to do with the quality of my work.
Charles Wheeler WHISPERS to Belinda Conine.
Your Honor, Mr. Beckett's incompetence nearly sabotaged a 350 million dollar suit.
was the one who was sabotaged.
We have complaints about Mr. Beckett's lack of preparation, his disorganization, his arrogant, defensive attitude... The list goes on.
We have letters.
Why haven't you produced these letters?
Take it easy. (to Wheeler) What's the big deal, Chuck? The boy wants a letter, to show to his mother, for her to keep after he's gone. Why are you being hard- assed about this?
I wish I could exonerate you, Andy. But I'd have to lie to do it.
(very calm) You can save it for the jury, Charles. I want to hear you say, under oath, in front of a judge and a jury, I'm a bad lawyer. (rises) Gentlemen. (to Belinda) Counselor.
Don't do this, Andy.
Whoa, whoa... (to Andrew) What do you expect them to say, you're Alan Dershowitz?
A trial takes
time , Beckett. Do you know what I'm saying?
I think I catch your subtle drift, Walter.
Andrew saunters out.
You'll be sorry, Beckett.
Andy, you don't want this.
Joe scans the room, all eyes are on him. His frown turns a grin. He faces the Judge.
With all due respect, Your Honor, my client chooses to pursue his constitutionally guaranteed right to a trial.
Joe exits.
Colonial house in Downington, Pennsylvania (EXT./DAY) ... Andrew walks toward the house, TALKING DIRECTLY TO CAMERA
This is the house where I grew up. In Downington, Pennsylvania. (pointing to the ground) See this... ?
The CAMERA POINTS to SEVERAL PAIRS OF CHILD'S HAND PRINTS sidewalk, then, BACK TO ANDREW IN CLOSE UP, SMILING.
Those are my cute little hand prints. And my brother's and my sister's.
And today is... ?
Today is my parents' fortieth wedding anniversary.
Andrew goes inside, speaking to the CAMERA:
This is the front door. I caught a finger in this door, once... (holds it up) This one. Broke it. (stepping inside) This is the hallway, my mother calls it a foyer...
CHILDREN are running through the house, while WOMEN sport corsages confer in the kitchen. A SIX YEAR OLD GIRL jumps Andrew's arms.
Uncle Andrew!
(to CAMERA) This is my niece, Alexis. Say hello, Alexis.
Mommy's pregnant again.
(doing Walter Cronkite) You heard it here first, folks. News as it happens.
Andrew's older and very down to earth sister JILL, puts h arms around Andrew, squeezing tight.
Hello, darlin'.
This is my sister, Jill, the most fertile woman on the planet. She's married to Reverend Jim.
You feel thin. (over Andrew's shoulder) Hello, Miguel.
As Jill leaves Andrew's arms, the CAMERA IS TRADED OFF TO ANDREW, who SHOOTS JILL GIVING MIGUEL A HUG.
Hey, Jill. Nice to see you, sweetheart.
(hugging Miguel) Handsome devil. (referring to Andrew) Is he eating?
We don't discuss his weight. (to Andrew, behind CAMERA) Do we?
And what will we find in... da duh da duh da duh... the KITCHEN!
when CAMERA ENTERS KITCHEN.
There he is! Hi, Andrew! Don't point that thing at me! etc...
Andrew's mother Sarah wears an unpretentious flowery dres
Hi, Mom. How do you feel on your fortieth anniversary?
Ancient. How do you think I feel? Put that thing down and give me a hug. (he keeps it pointed at her) Andrew, stop! ... He still doesn't listen.
Where's Dad?
He's out in his shed showing your uncle his new riding mower.
One of Andrew's YOUNG NEPHEWS SHOVES HIS FACE into the

Andrew and his immediate family are gathered in the den, quietly, facing each other. Andrew's father, BUD, with an American flag pin in his lapel, sits next to Sarah. Jill the hand of her husband, REVEREND JIM. Two of Andrew's br MATT and RANDY, (big, athletic guys with mustaches) are t Andrew sits next to Miguel.
Things might be said, at the trial, that... are not going to be easy for you to hear. Things about me, about my private life. And I want to make sure it's okay with everybody.
I appreciate you asking, Andy, but really, it's your call.
What do you think, Jill?

To be honest, I'm worried about Mommy and Daddy. They've had to go through so much already... And, we all know... (very difficult to say) There's going to be even worse things to deal with, eventually. I wonder if it's fair to put them through this.
Andrew's father STARES at his folded hands.
Mom?

All I know is, you got through your diagnosis fine, like a trooper. But when they fired you... you were so devastated, Andy... I don't expect any of my kids to sit in the back of the bus. Fight for your rights.
Thanks, Mom... Dad?
There's a pause before Bud Beckett speaks.
Supposedly, the Lord doesn't give you more trouble than you can handle. But I'm having a hard time believing that these days.
Andrew's construction worker brother, RANDY, wipes tears from his eyes. Clearly their father is in alot of pain.
Andy, the way you've faced this whole thing, you and Miguel, with so much courage... your mother and I have been so very impressed...
Andrew gazes at his father with incredible love. Miguel p an arm around Andrew.
I can't imagine there is anything, that anyone could say, that would make us feel less proud of you.
(full of emotion) Thanks, Dad. I love you guys. How about you, Randy?
Hey. You're my kid brother, Andy. That's the bottom line. I mean, what are those bastards going to say? You're gay? Shit, I knew that when you were five years old.
Everyone LAUGHS. Andrew and Randy high five.
Wait a minute... (to Andrew) You're
gay
More laughter. But Jill speaks seriously:
What about you, Andy? You're not a militant type. You've always been so private.
I guess... I don't have time for that any more.
Jim? Will you lead us in a prayer?
Everyone bows heads, holding hands in a circle.
Dear Lord. Sometimes it is difficult to remember to be grateful...

To remember, in our times of sorrow and confusion, that we have You to turn to, and each other. Bless and keep Andrew and Miguel, dear Lord, deepen and strengthen their love as they face the struggles that lay ahead. Bless and watch over all of us, fill us with Your love, Your light, and Your peace, which passeth all understanding. In Jesus' name, we pray...
Amen.

head_text.subj: BECKETTS' LIVINGROOM, SEEN THROUGH THE VIDEO CAMERA, (DAY)

text: A local entertainer (GUIDO PAONESSA) launches into a standard, accompanied by a single guitar player, and Bud Sarah begin to dance, surrounded by family and friends.
"After all the days of Spring have flown..."

VIDEO CAMERA PANS: RELATIVES eating cake, KIDS chasing ea other, a GRANDMOTHER in a wheelchair holding a NEWBORN, watching silent, video home movies. CAMERA FINDS Andrew and Niguel eating anniversary cake (Andrew barely touches his). Playing for the camera, Migu dips his finger into icing and smears it onto Andrew's no Andrew tries to reach the icing with his tongue. CAMERA PANS WITH ANDREW as he comes forward to dance with mother, while Jill dances with their father. CAMERA RETURNS TO MIGUEL. MATT (behind the camera) says:
Hey, Miguel, can you imagine any two people being together for forty years?
ZOOM IN CLOSE ON NIGUEL (who's watching Andrew):
Yes. I can.
VIDEO CAMERA PANS to Andrew dancing with his Mom, lingeri this IMAGE...
Forget everything you've seen on TV, and in the movies...
Eight months later.
There won't be any last minute, surprise witnesses...
American, a Marine (INT./DAY) ...
Opening statements.
The MARINE is a JUROR. CAMERA PANS others: a BLACK LADY SCHOOLTEACHER, a POSTAL WORKER, an ASIAN COLLEGE STUDENT.
No one will break down on the stand with a tearful confession...

head_text.subj: REVERSE ON JOE, ADDRESSING THE JURY.

text: You are presented with a simple fact: Andrew Beckett was fired. You will hear two explanations for why he was fired. Ours. And theirs...

Joe crosses the courtroom, coming to stand in front of... ANDREW, whose appearance has changed:  thinner, paler than we've ever seen him, some blisters on his lips. But the most di thing about his appearance is the way he moves, slowly, l much older man. He's taking notes (which he will do relentlessly throughout the trial.) And he has a cane at side, which he'll use throughout the trial.
It's up to you, to sift through layer and layer of truth, and determine for yourselves the version that sounds the

most true. Charles Wheeler, Walter Kenton, Bob Seidman, Kenneth Kill sit BEHIND their lawyers, Belinda Conine and Jerome Green SEVERAL ASSISTANTS at the defense table. JUDGE GARNETT presides from his bench. Among the spectators, Miguel sits next to Sarah, and Andrew's sister Jill. AIDS ACTIVISTS in the background.

There are certain points in our version, that I must prove to you... Point number one: Andrew Beckett was... is a brilliant lawyer. A great lawyer. Point number two. Andrew Beckett, afflicted with a debilitating disease, made the legal, understandable, personal choice to keep the fact of his illness to himself... Point number three: His employers discovered his illness. And ladies and gentlemen, the illness I'm referring to, is AIDS...
Joe pauses, letting that sink in.
Point number four. They panicked. And, in their panic, they did what most of us would like to do with AIDS... Get it, and the people who have it, as far away from us as possible.
Joe walks away from Andrew.
The behavior of Andrew Beckett's employers may seem reasonable to you. It does to me. After all, AIDS is a deadly, incurable, disease...
But however you come to judge the behavior of Charles Wheeler and his partners in moral, ethical, human terms... When they fired Andrew Beckett because he had AIDS,
they broke the law . With a swift, direct glance at the Judge, Joe speaks with considerable power and emotion:

And, when lawyers break the law, when this society loses respect for the law, when that day comes, our cherished institutions will be burned to the ground, and our children and grandchildren will live like savages.

Fact. Andrew Beckett performed at a consistently mediocre level. Fact. He made a grievous error on a multi-million dollar lawsuit... Fact. He claims he is the victim of lies and deceit. Fact. Andrew Beckett lied to his employers, going to great efforts to conceal his disease from them. Fact. He was successful in his duplicity. The partners at Wyant Wheeler did
not know Andrew Beckett had AIDS when they fired him...
Belinda pauses in front of the plaintiff's table
Fact. AIDS is a tragedy...
Andrew looks directly at Belinda.
Fact. Andrew Beckett is dying.
Joe watches Andrew for his reaction.
Fact. Andrew Beckett is angry. Because his "lifestyle," his reckless behavior, has cut short his life... And in his anger, his rage, he's lashing out. And he wants someone to
pay .
large insurance company, MR. LAIRD (INT./DAY) ...
Andrew Beckett represented your company in a lawsuit in 1990, is that correct?
Wyant Wheeler represented us.
Andrew glances toward the jury box: the MARINE JUROR writ tiny notebook.
But, Andrew Beckett was in charge of litigation for the suit.
That's correct.
Were you pleased with his work?
We were satisfied.
Joe and Andrew exchange a LOOK -- Laird's response surpri disappoints them.
Were you satisfied, or were you pleased?
Laird glances toward Charles Wheeler before answering.
We were satisfied.
Joe refers to legal documents.
Mr. Laird, when I approached you about being a witness at this trial, and you agreed, you gave sworn testimony in a deposition. Is that correct?
That's correct.
According to the deposition, you said you were "thrilled, impressed, overwhelmed" by the quality of Andrew Beckett's work. Do you remember saying that?
I may have said something like that. But that's not how I feel at this moment.
Joe takes on a street-tough tone:
Okay, Mr. Laird. Explain this to me like I'm a four year old: Did Andrew Beckett win your lawsuit for you or not?
We won.
Did that thrill, impress and overwhelm you?
It satisfied me.
Joe STARES at the guy.

It's a long way between being overwhelmed and being satisfied. A cheeseburger may be satisfying whereas caviar and champagne and roast duck and baked Alaska for dessert might be considered overwhelming. Do you agree?
I might.
Five months ago you characterized Andrew Beckett as caviar and now you're calling him a cheeseburger. Your standards have shifted a great deal, and I'd like to know why you've changed your mind.
Since that time I've devoted more thought to the subject, and that's how I feel now.
Partner Robert Seidman was the supervising attorney for your lawsuit?
That's right.
Does the supervising attorney guide the litigating attorney during the trial?
Often, he does.
As far as you know, in the handling of your lawsuit, Andrew Beckett was simply following orders.
That's a fair assessment of the situation.
Andrew glances over his shoulder: at Robert Seidman, who meets his gaze.

head_text.subj: SPECTATORS STREAM OUT OF CITY HALL INTO THE HUBBUB OF TWO
DISTINCT GROUPS SHOUTING AT EACH OTHER, (EXT/DAY)

text: ACTIVISTS in T-shirts with pink triangles, denouncing discrimination; BORN AGAIN ACTIVISTS waving placards citi as God's punishment for homosexuality; POLICEMEN keeping apart; A MEDIA CIRCUS getting it on videotape. Joe and Miguel FLANK Andrew, who  walks weakly. with a cane . Sarah and Jill follow close behind, running the gauntlet ACTIVISTS and REPORTERS. Andrew's POV on a placard: "We Die - They Do Nothing!" Jill's POV on a placard: "AIDS Cures Homosexuality!" A TV CREW shines HOT LIGHTS on Andrew.
Do you see this as a gay rights issue?
I'm not political. I just want compensation for being fired.
But you are gay, aren't you?
"I don't see how that's any of your business... (a smile) But yes, I am."

head_text.subj: O'CLOCK NEWS WITH FILKO, A LOCAL COP, OTHERS, (INT./NIGHT)

text: : A microphone is shoved at Joe.
"Do you believe that homosexuals deserve special treatment?"

Hell, no! JOE (on TV) "Angela, we're standing in Philadelphia, the City of Brotherly Love, the birthplace of freedom, where our Founding Fathers authored the Declaration of Independence. And I don't remember that glorious document saying "All
straight men are created equal." I could have sworn it says, "All men are created equal."
Give me a goddamn break!
: The REPORTER wraps up her story.

"This case is sending a cold chill through the legal community. One of Wyant Wheeler's key clients, the Grace Foster Foundation, which supports several AIDS charities, has taken its business to another firm until this matter is resolved..."
As the TV DRONES ON, CHARLIE THE COP, OTHERS GLARE at Joe
(chuckles) Hey, Joe. (a wink to the COP) You're not starting to get a little... light on your feet here on us, are you?
Joe does not laugh.

Yeah, Filko. I am. (stepping toward Filko) I'm on the prowl, Filko. I need a man. Not just any man. I need a hunk. A hunk like you. How about it, Filko? Want to play sailor? This time, I'll be first mate and you can be Columbus.
Chill out, Joe.
(angry) Those people make me sick, Filko! But a law's been broken, okay? The
law . Remember the law?
CHARLIE THE COP has relaxed a bit.
At least we agree on one thing, Joe... They make me sick too.
HOLD ON JOE, but WE HEAR THE TV REPORTER in the BACKGROUN
"... now the public knows that your son has AIDS and he's gay. How does that make you feel?"
All eyes turn to the TV: SARAH BECKETT IN CLOSE UP.
"This is a world full of war, famine, poverty, homelessness... and people make a fuss because two men or two women want to live together, or make love. Seems kind of silly, doesn't it?"
The bar ERUPTS with a CHORUS OF BOOS AND CATCALLS.

head_text.subj: JOE ADDRESSING A WITNESS IN COURT, (INT./DAY)

text: And Walter Kenton knew the lesions on your face and arms were caused by AIDS?
The witness: MARIA TORRES, Hispanic, 35, healthy-looking.
Definitely. People were going around, whispering things. I figured I didn't have anything to lose, so I told all the partners.
How did Walter Kenton treat you, after you told him you had AIDS?
CLOSE ON KENTON, looking confident.
Every time he came into contact with me, he'd get this look on his face. I called it, the "Oh God" expression. As in "Oh God, here comes that woman with AIDS."
Andrew LAUGHS.
Ms. Torres? Have your employers fired you for having AIDS?
No. When I need time off, for medical reasons, we work it out.
Thank you. No more questions.
Jerome Green rises.
Miss Torres. How did you contract the AIDS virus?
During a transfusion. I lost a lot of blood giving birth to my second child.
In other words, in
your case you happen to be an innocent victim of the AIDS tragedy.
Look. I'm no different from everyone else who has this disease: I'm not guilty, I'm not innocent. I'm just trying to survive.
Beyond noticing the marks on his face, were there other things about his appearance that made you suspect he had AIDS?
THE WITNESS: Paralegal Anthea Burton.
He was losing weight. He looked kind of tired sometimes. But he was working so hard... Still, I felt something was wrong. (looking at Wheeler) And I can't believe
they're saying they didn't notice anything.
Objection.
Just answer the question.
Sorry.
Ms. Burton. You're black.
Is that a question?
No. Have you ever felt discriminated against, at Wyant Wheeler?
Yes.
Wheeler shakes his head, disgusted. Kenton fumes, outrage Seidman looks surprised.
In what way?
Well... One time, Mr. Wheeler's secretary, Lydia, told me Mr. Wheeler had a problem with my earrings.
Your earrings?
Anthea is wearing large, dangling African-style earrings.
Apparently, Mr. Wheeler felt they were too... "ethnic" is the word she used. She said he would like it if I wore something smaller, less garish, and... more "American."
What did you say?
I said my earrings
are American. They're African-American.
Thank you. No more questions.
Belinda Conine approaches Anthea.
Miss Burton? Do you still work at Wyant Wheeler?
Yes.
Were you recently promoted?
Yes. I'm now in charge of the paralegal department.
Thank you.

head_text.subj: A PHILADELPHIA EXTERIOR, A FALL AFTERNOON, (LATE DAY)
JOE COMES DOWN AN AISLE OF A DRUG STORE, EXAMINING THE BA

text: cold medicines, carrying a box of Pampers (INT./DAY) ... A YOUNG MAN in grass-stained sweats, carrying a football one arm, buying a tube of toothpaste, speaks to Joe:
How's the trial going? It's a great case.
Joe looks up surprised. The YOUNG MAN smiles.
I saw you on television. I'm a law student. At Penn.
Joe is flattered by the YOUNG MAN'S interest.
Good school. What year?
Second.
Great.
Would you like to have a drink with me? I just finished a game, I could use a beer. (a smile) I don't pick up people in drug stores every day.
Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa... do you think... ? You think
I'm ... (low) ... gay?
Aren't you?
What's the matter with you? Do I look gay to you?
Do I look gay to you? Relax.
Relax? I ought to kick your faggoty little ass for you!
Take it as a compliment. Geesh.
But Joe is really upset. People are watching.
Don't you know this is exactly the kind of bullshit that makes people hate you guys?
Fuck you! You want to kick my ass? You want to try? (walking away) Asshole.
You're the asshole, buddy.
(going out) Get a life.
Joe stands there, holding the Pampers, people STARING.

head_text.subj: LISA'S WORKING ON HER COMPUTER, AT HOME, WHILE JOE PACES

text: around her desk, really upset (One year-old Rayisha sits the desk playing with wooden salad spoons.) (INT./NIGHT)
But what was it?! What was this guy thinking... ?!
Don't know, Joe.

Is there some kind of expression I've picked up from Beckett?! Some kind of fairy attitude I've unconsciously adopted?! Am I walking different?! Some kind of vocal thing?! Have I picked up some kind of homo
vibe
Have you changed your aftershave?
Very funny. I had a box of Pampers under my arm for Chrissake!

head_text.subj: LISA AND JOE'S DARKENED BEDROON, WHERE THEY LIE IN BED,

text: almost completely obscured by shadow (INT./NIGHT) ... They speak softly, careful not to wake the baby.
Joe?
(sleepy) Yeah... ?
Two men making love... ? Now tell me again...
why is that disgusting?
(a tired sigh) Lisa, c'mon. One guy sticking his dick in another guy's mouth? It's disgusting.
They lie in silence for a moment. Then:
Okay, so... help me with this one, Joe... Is it disgusting for someone to put his dick into someone's mouth? Or, is it disgusting for someone to take a dick into
their mouth?
(after a beat) Great, Lisa. Thank you.
"But, ultimately, the complaint was found, wasn't it?
Yes. We found a copy. It been incorrectly filed...
Plaintiff's case, day ten.
We got it to court on time.
ANGLE ON THE JURY: Several JURORS write in notebooks like Marine's; he's been handing them out... Joe seems ill at ease today, a little off his game. When glances at Andrew, it's with irritation.
Has a file ever disappeared like that before? Vanished into thin air, all of a sudden, only to reappear in the nick of time?
Jamey answers nervously:
I've never known that to happen before. No.
(fires this question) Did you have something to do with this file being lost accidentally-on-purpose?
Objection!
I'll rephrase. (to Jamey) Did you have anything to do with this file being... misplaced?
Absolutely not.
Joe stands, staring at Jamey. Too long. Jamey squirms.
Are you a homosexual?
What?!
Joe pressing forward, toward Jamey.
C'mon, Mr. Collins. Are you homosexual? You know, gay?
The COURTROOM ERUPTS: ACTIVISTS booing Joe, Wheeler's cro expressing OUTRAGE, JURORS looking confused. Andrew takes in the commotion, as the JUDGE BANGS HIS GAV
Hold it, hold it!
Andrew trains his attention on Joe.
Objection! Where has this come from?! Suddenly Counsel is attacking his own witness. Mr. Collins' sexual orientation has absolutely no relevance to this case.
I said, HOLD IT! (the courtroom QUIETS) Mr. Miller. Could you kindly share with me exactly what's going on in your brain, because I don't have a clue at the moment.
Joe faces Andrew, also curious to know what Joe's up to.

Your Honor, everyone in this courtroom is thinking about sexual preference, sexual orientation, whatever you want to call it. They're looking at me, and wondering about it...
