(looking at Andrew) They're looking at Mr. Beckett, and wondering about it. They're looking at Mr. Wheeler and wondering about it. They might even be looking at you and wondering about it. So, let's get it out in the open. Let's talk about what this case is really about: the general public's hatred... our loathing, our
fear of homosexuals.
DEAD SILENCE while the Judge thinks it over. CLOSE ON ANDREW.
(to himself) Very good.
CLOSE ON JAMEY COLLINS, sweating bullets on the stand.
In this courtroom, Mr. Miller, justice is blind. To matters of race, creed, color, religion. And sexual orientation.
With all due respect, Your Honor... We don't live in this courtroom, do we?
No. We don't... However, as regards this witness, I'm going to sustain the defense's objection.

head_text.subj: COURTHOUSE MEN'S ROOM, FIVE URINALS, THREE SINKS

text: The MARINE JUROR, the RETIRED POSTAL WORKER JUROR, and AN UPTIGHT BUSINESSMAN JUROR stand at the urinals, with an e urinal between each of them. The MARINE JUROR whistles wh he pees (a classic rock tune, like "Radar Love.") The BUSINESSMAN sighs, "Ahhhhhh." The RETIRED POSTAL WORKER JUROR jingles change. The ROCK MUSICIAN JUROR enters, stepping up to the urinal between the BUSINESSMAN and the MARINE. He unzips, and it to take him an incredibly long time to extricate his urin organ. This does  not escape the MARINE'S notice.
(innocently, to Marine) I have some gay friends. What's the biggie?
The MARINE says nothing.
Everybody has a couple of gay friends. Don't you?
No, sir. I do not.
The MARINE moves closer to the urinal, so that no one can his private parts.
You might have them, and just not know they're gay.
The MARINE shakes, zips, flushes, turns away. He pauses t directly at the ROCK MUSICIAN JUROR.
I know.

head_text.subj: WALTER KENTON ON THE WITNESS STAND, (INT./DAY)

text: And how many weeks at a time would you be out to sea, without stopping at port?
Anywhere from two weeks, to several months.
Any women on board?
Kenton glances at the MARINE JUROR.
Not when I was in the Navy.

So during those long voyages, months at a time, out to sea, no women in sight, a hundred, hardworking, robust, young men, in the prime of their life, at the peak of their natural appetites, desires, their god- given, hormonal
instincts ... Anything going on?
Going on... like...?
Like... two sailors playing hide the salami.
Andrew covers his face with his hands.
Objection!
Mr. Miller!
(can't resist) We had one guy like that.
You haven't ruled on my objection, Your Honor.
Kenton seems eager to tell his story. Joe stands with crossed arms, waiting.
Let's continue.
(to Kenton) You had one guy "like that?"
Yeah. But we took care of him.
How did you do that?
We stuck his head in the latrine, after ten of us had used it.
LAUGHTER and SOME APPLAUSE from some SPECTATORS, and some JURORS. ACTIVISTS BOO and HISS. The JUDGE POUNDS HIS GAVEL.
You taught him a lesson.
Yes, we did.
Like firing Andrew Beckett taught
him a lesson?
Objection!
I'll withdraw. (moving on quickly) You were aware, when you worked with Maria Torres, that she had AIDS, correct?
She didn't try to conceal it.
So you are aware of the difference between a lesion and a bruise, is that correct?
I
know the difference. That doesn't mean I'm always able to recognize the difference.
But didn't you avoid contact with Ms. Torres, after you found out she had AIDS? She says you acted repulsed by her and you avoided her, is that correct?
I felt, and still feel, nothing but the deepest sympathy and compassion for people like Maria, who have contracted this terrible disease through no fault of their own.

head_text.subj: IN THE KITCHEN OF THEIR APARTMENT, MIGUEL POURS MEDICINE

text: into an IV drip unit (INT./NIGHT) ... LOUD CLASSICAL MUSIC IN THE BACKGROUND. Miguel glances at a chart on the wall, in which a day is broken into hours, with medical instructions for each hou
(shouting over MUSIC) Drew! Are you ready? If we start at eight, we'll be done by twelve.
Miguel taps the IV bag, getting the drip started. A cat jumps onto the counter. Miguel holds it.

head_text.subj: ANDREW SITS AT THE DININGROOM TABLE, MAKING NOTES ON A LE

text: pad, holding out his left arm (INT./NIGHT). A catheter is imbedded into Andrew's arm, and Miguel is trying to get t IV drip started through the catheter. The MUSIC is lower.
It's not going through.
(focused on his work) We'll have to flush it again.
Andrew reaches for a law book.
Hold still. Shit. (trying again) The goddamn vein's clotted. We have to go the goddamn hospital, so they can change the goddamn catheter.
I have too much work to do. Skip the treatment.
We're not skipping this treatment.
I said, skip it, Michael. It's my treatment.
Fuck you.
Fuck you. This shit's probably not doing me any good anyway.
That shit's saving your life, you asshole!
Miguel shoves away from the table.
What's wrong with you?
Close the law book.
I'm not going to close the--
CLOSE THE FUCKING LAW BOOK!
Andrew slams it SHUT.
ALLRIGHT IT'S CLOSED! (beat) Jesus!
The least you can do is look at me, while I'm sticking this shit into your arm. Forget the fucking case, one hour a day, and give me a little of your time.
(very quiet) You don't think there's much time left, do you?
That's not what I said.
You're scared. You think we're near the end.
No.
Maybe I should start making plans, is that what you think? Start planning my memorial service? "Begin to prepare for the inevitable."
(low) Maybe you should think about it.
What's that mean?!
(very difficult) Maybe you should think about it.
I'm not going to die.
That's right. We're on the Positive Plan. You don't have a Fatal Disease, you have Manageable Illness.
You want me to give up? Let this thing turn us into
victims
Then, what
are we, Drew?! The winners ? "Ladies and gentlemen, the first prize of AIDS goes to Andrew Beckett and his lover Miguel..." Excuse me, I'm not your lover. I'm your Care Partner. FUCK!
I'm not ready to die.
Do you think I'm ready for it?! I hate this shit. I'm not a fucking martyr! I hate every goddamn part of it!
Miguel slides down the wall, sitting in a heap. Andrew goes to him. They hug. Miguel holds him tight.
Please don't leave me. I love you so much. Don't die, don't leave me, please...
Miguel rocks in Andrew's arms. Andrew kisses the top of h head, holding tight.
I am so scared. I am so fucking, incredibly, fucking scared...
A MOMENT. Andrew stroking Miguel's hair, as he calms down
You know, there's only one thing to do. (beat) We have to have a party.

head_text.subj: JOE AND LISA STAND OUTSIDE ANDREW'S APARTMENT

text: DANCE MUSIC is playing inside (INT./NIGHT) ... Lisa is dressed as a giant sandwich. Joe's costume looks thrown together: he's wearing a suit, but has pages from document stapled all over the suit.
Did I ever tell you, I hate costume parties?
My lettuce is wilting.
The DOOR IS OPENED -- by the LEAD SINGER OF WHITE SNAKE: hair, leather, guitar.
PARRTYY!
We're friends of Beckett's.
It's me, you dork.
I'm Lisa Miller.
Glad to finally meet you. Come on in.

head_text.subj: JOE AND LISA FOLLOW ANDREW INTO THE APARTMENT

text: HE LIMPS, relying on his cane, but he's got A LOT OF ENERGY ). The room is filled with two Madonnas, an M.C. Hammer, three nuns, a can of s (INT./NIGHT) ...
(to Lisa) I have to introduce you to the can of soup. You can enter the costume contest together as a lunch special.
Miguel approaches, dressed as a MEMBER OF MEGA-DEATH or A He strikes a pose, contorts his face and hits an air guit Andrew crosses guitars with Miguel. Then:
This is Lisa Miller. Miguel Alvarez.
Miguel's sister MARIA is passing by with a GROUP OF FRIEN Everyone ad libs greetings.
My sister, Maria. (to Lisa) Pastrami on rye?
Corned beef.
Want to dance?
Sure!
Miguel leads Lisa away. Joe is reluctant to give her up.
Beckett. You seem... better. Energized, more alive...
I had a blood transfusion today. I feel great.
Andrew studies Joe, trying to figure out the costume.
I'm a law suit.
Not bad.
Get it?
Let's find you a drink.

Andrew leads Joe through the crowd, greeting Rachel, skin painted blue (SMURFETTE) her daughter AMY (BART SIMPSON), Anthea, TYRONE from Dr. Gillman's office (A COWBOY), and TYRONE'S LOVER (A HORSE) ... Some of Dr. Gillman's PATIEN are here too, including the YOUNG ASIAN MAN who is now in wheelchair. And, one or two of ANDREW'S SIBLINGS may be present as well. And Alan, Bruno and Chandra, and some ar friends and neighbors.
What do you want?
Beer. (patting his briefcase) We need to go over your Q and A.
Excuse me, I'm having a goddamn party, is that allright with you?
Sure. It's fine.
No, we have to do it. But later, allright?
Thank you.
A MAN dressed as LA TOYA JACKSON (with fake snake) squeez past Joe, reaching for a beer.
'Scuse me, darling.
Andrew is SMILING at Joe.
You think I'm uncomfortable...
Correct.
You're right.
Joe spills beer down his shirt.
Thank you.

head_text.subj: CUT TO A SERIES OF PARTY MOMENTS OVER LOUD MUSIC

text: --Andrew and Miguel ROCKING to HEAVY METAL MUSIC, playing battle of the guitars. At one point, Andrew has to sit down, but he doesn't stop "playing," while Miguel jumps a around him. --Joe talking to a MAN DRESSED AS MARIE ANTOINETTE:
I'm an accountant. What do you do?
I'm a lawyer. (points to Lisa) That's my wife!
--Andrew's mother Sarah, as Marge Simpson, delivers a tra of hors d'oeuvres to Joe (standing next to a POLICEMAN):
Have a cocktail wienie.
Thanks, Sarah. (to the POLICEMAN) Nice costume.
It's not a costume, I just got off work. You're cute.
(pointing to Lisa) That's my wife. Want to see a picture of my baby?
(reaching for
his wallet) Absolutely. Want to see a picture of

my baby? --Everyone SLOW DANCES to the Talking Heads tune "Heaven" (Simply Red cover version): Joe and Lisa, Andrew and Miguel, Rachel with a sleepy Amy in her arms, the POLICEM and TYRONE, Sarah Beckett and MARIE ANTOINETTE, LA TOYA a her snake.

head_text.subj: A CAB IDLING IN THE STREET, LISA KISSING JOE, (NIGHT)

text: I'll see you in an hour, max.
Night, honey.
Lisa climbs into the cab which she is sharing with the NU and MARIE ANTOINETTE and LA TOYA.
Night, Joe!

head_text.subj: QUIET IN ANDREW'S CONDO, THE PARTY LONG OVER, (INT/NIGHT)

text: Joe opens his briefcase, removing a legal pad with notes.
Congratulations, Miller.

Andrew clears away party debris from the table, making sp for his legal work. He is attached to an IV line, which i connected to a drip bag on a rolling stand, that can move with him. He is no longer in costume.
You survived your first gay party intact.

Let me tell you something, okay? When you're brought up, like the rest of us, in a place like where I was brought up, there's not a whole lot of discussion about... homosexuals. As a kid, you're taught right away that queers are weird, queers are funny, they're a danger to kids, they're afraid to fight, and they all want to cop your joint. And that pretty much sums up the general thinking out there, if you want to know the truth.
Thank you for sharing that with me, Joe.
Let's review these notes for your testimony. We have a big day on Monday.
Joe begins ticking off a list of courtroom reminders:
When you refer to Wheeler, call him Charles, to show how you'd been admitted to the inner circle, you were considered one of them.
(distracted) Uh huh...
Beckett?
Charles. Okay. Miller?
What?
Do you... pray?
Joe hesitates. They're having a personal conversation?
Yeah. Sure.
Joe goes back to the notes:
Then we establish how Wheeler's boys recruited you after law school...
What have you prayed for?
For a healthy baby. For Lisa to make it through the delivery. For the Phillies to get into the playoffs.
(no self-pity) There's a possibility I won't be around for the end of this trial.
I've considered that.
What happens?
We proceed, representing your estate.
I've made provisions in my will for some charities. Miguel will need a lawyer. I know it's not your area...
I know a good probate lawyer.
Thanks. (a beat) Do you like opera?
Andrew moves to the stereo, pulling the IV line with him.
Opera?
Want to hear my favorite aria?
Opera?

head_text.subj: SUDDENLY, AN ARIA BY MARIA CALLAS FILLS THE ROOM --

text: startling Joe with its VOLUME.

(over the MUSIC) Andrea Chenier, by Giordano. This is Madeleine. She's telling how, during the French revolution, a mob set fire to her house. Her mother died, saving her. "I look... The place that cradled me was burning!" Do you hear the heartache in her voice? Then, here come the strings. Everything changes. The music fills with hope. Madeleine says...
Andrew sways through the room to the music, pulling the I at his side. He seems truly free and relaxed.

"It was during that sorrow that love came to me! A voice filled with harmony That said... Live still, I am Life!" "I am the god that descends From the heavens to the earth To make of the earth A heaven!"
ANGLE ON JOE: Shifting, uncomfortable.
"I am Oblivion! I am Glory! I am Love, Love, Love!"
The MUSIC ENDS. Joe sits there, fidgeting. He reaches for his briefcase organizing his notes.
I think I'll... I told Lisa.
Andrew collects himself, as Joe rises from his chair.
Right.
Andrew follows Joe to the door.
(businesslike) I'll look over the Q and A.
You're ready, don't worry.
An awkward moment, both men standing with their hands at their sides -- will one of them initiate a handshake? Joe gives a little "salute," then leaves.

head_text.subj: JOE COMES DOWN THE HALLWAY OF THE MODERN CONDO BUILDING

text: Jesus.
Suddenly, Joe HEARS: OPERA MUSIC PLAYING AGAIN. He pauses, listening.

head_text.subj: ANDREW MOVES THROUGH THE ROOM, DRINKING IN THE BEAUTIFUL,

text: passionate MUSIC (INT./NIGHT) ... The IV stand catches against the sofa, tugging the line. Andrew pulls the line out of his arm. He moves, freer now

head_text.subj: JOE STANDS OUTSIDE ANDREW'S DOOR, OPERA MUSIC PLAYING

text: Joe lifts his hand to KNOCK. He changes his mind.
Fucking guy...
Joe moves down the corridor, rings for the elevator.
MUSIC pull him along (INT./NIGHT) ...
The doors closing.
MUSIC FADING, CROSSES THE CUT TO:
Joe crosses the yard to his dark house. MUSIC DISTANT, CROSSES THE CUT TO:

head_text.subj: JOE'S BABY LIES SLEEPING IN HER CRIB, (INT./NIGHT)

text: Joe looks down on the baby, adjusting the blanket.

head_text.subj: LISA FACES CAMERA, ASLEEP IN THE DARK BEDROOM

text: Joe doffs his jacket, sinking quietly onto the edge of th bed, careful not to disturb Lisa. With his BACK TO CAMERA, Joe puts his head into his hands And begins to weep. FADE OUT. FADE IN: PANORAMIC SHOT OF PHILADELPHIA EXTERIORS...

Andrew moves very slowly with his cane across the courtro toward the witness stand. --JUDGE GARNETT crosses his arms, waiting. --JOE glances at some notes. --MIGUEL and SARAH BECKETT look on anxiously. --WHEELER and the others observe in silence.

head_text.subj: CAMERA HOLDS ON BIBLE BEING CARRIED IN GLOVED HANDS, ACRO

text: Plaintiff's case. day fourteen.
The BAILIFF places the Bible in front of Andrew ( a purple blotch is showing in front of Andrew's ear
Place your left hand on the Bible and raise your right hand.
Andrew places his hand on the Bible.
"Do you swear to tell the truth... DIALOGUE OVERLAP AND DISSOLVE TO:

head_text.subj: ANDREW ANSWERING A QUESTION AN HOUR OR SO LATER

text: Wyant Wheeler had aggressively recruited me. They were the most prestigious firm in Philadelphia, full of opportunity. And I was impressed by the partners.
Including Charles Wheeler?
Andrew frequently wipes sweat from his forehead with a handkerchief. His voice is hoarse, raspy.
Particularly, Charles.
What impressed you about him?
He was... the kind of person I thought I wanted to be.
What kind of person is that?

Possessed of an encyclopedic knowledge of the law. A razor sharp litigator, a genuine leader, gifted at bringing out the very best in others. An awesome ability to illuminate the most complex of legal concepts to colleagues, courtrooms, the person on the street. (a smile) The kind of person who plays three sets of tennis but doesn't sweat. But underneath the elegant surface, was an adventurous spirit.
Belinda Conine MAKES A NOTE ABOUT THAT.
Obviously, at this time, you weren't sick.
It's possible I was infected with the HIV virus at that time, but I wasn't diagnosed until several years later.
You didn't look then, the way you look now?
The healthy. pre-AIDS Andrew.
No. I was thirty pounds heavier. I was athletic.
A regular all-American guy?
I suppose you could say that.
Except... you were gay?
I still am.
In the years you worked at Wyant Wheeler, did you ever tell Charles Wheeler you were gay?
No. I didn't.
Can you explain
why you didn't?
You don't bring your personal life into a law firm. You're not supposed to
have a personal life, really. Anyway, I did plan to tell Charles, eventually. But then, this thing happened at the tennis club...

head_text.subj: A TENNIS CLUB, WEARING TOWELS, ENTERING A SAUNA

text: Longstreet's interested in the Harrisburg deal.
I'm seeing him this afternoon.
"Somebody started telling jokes."
What do you call a woman who has PMS and ESP at the same time?.
What?
A bitch who knows everything.
LAUGHTER. Andrew keeps his eyes closed, leaning against t wall of the sauna, next to Wheeler, relaxing.
How does a faggot fake an orgasm?
Andrew opens one eye.
He spits on your back.
Charles, that's revolting!
All the men LAUGH, and Wheeler LAUGHS THE HARDEST.
How did that make you feel?
it's the sick, thin Andrew with AIDS).
Relieved. That I'd never told him I was gay. Very relieved.
ANGLE ON CHARLES WHEELER: shakes his head, a denial.
Are you a good lawyer?
I'm an excellent lawyer.
What makes you an excellent lawyer?
I love the law. I know the law. I excel at practicing it. It's the only thing I've ever wanted to do.
What do you love about it?

Well... many things. But I think the thing I love the most, is that every once in a while, not that often, but occasionally... you get to be part of justice being done. It's really quite a thrill when that happens.
You said earlier you aspired to be the kind of person who had "an adventurous spirit." Is that correct?
Something like that.
Do you take risks?
In my work? Yes. Calculated risks. You have to.
In general. Do you take risks in other areas of your life?
Not unnecessary ones.
Have you ever been to the Apollo Cinema on Sansom Street?
Joe cringes a little with discomfort.
(looking Belinda right in the eye) A few times.
What kind of movies do they show there?
Gay movies.
Gay
pornographic movies?
Yes.
Do men have sex with each other in that theater?
Yes.
How about you, Mr. Beckett?
(INT./DAY)
... Have you ever had sex with someone in that theater?
Yes.
Once.
I'm Robert.
Andrew.
Andrew steps into the booth.
Now what do we do?
Robert laughs, closing the door of the booth.
I think we'll figure it out.
Joe sits with a stone-sober expression: this isn't easy.
When? Approximately what year did this event take place?
I guess it was 1984, 85.
Were you aware in 1984 or 1985 that there was a fatal disease out there, called AIDS, and that you could contract it through sexual activity?
It's impossible to know exactly when or how I was infected with HIV.
But you
were having anonymous sex in porno theaters in 1984 and 1985?
That happened once. People weren't talking about AIDS then, the way we are now. Or safe sex.
You'd
heard of AIDS in 1984, 85?
I'd heard of
something . The gay plague, gay cancer, but... we didn't know how you could get it, or that it could kill you.
CLOSE SHOT ON ANDREW -- losing strength.
(sounds far away) Do you need a break?
No.
While you were employed at Wyant Wheeler, you did everything you could to make sure no one knew you were an active homosexual, correct?
That is
not correct. I never lied about it.
Did you keep a picture of your lover on your desk?
No.
Do other lawyers at the firm keep pictures of their spouses or fiances on their desks?

head_text.subj: PHOTO ON THE WALL OF BOB'S WIFE AND CHILDREN

text: Some do. I didn't.
As a homosexual, one is often forced to conceal one's sexuality, is that right?
In some situations.
Isn't it true you have spent your life pretending to be something you're not, so much so that the art of concealment and dishonesty has become second nature to you?!
Objection!
I'll withdraw it. Mr. Beckett? Were you living with Miguel Alvarez in 1984 or 1985 when you had your anonymous sexual encounter in the porn theater?
ANGLE ON MIGUEL, sitting next to Sarah.
Yes.
You could have infected him, isn't that right?
Miguel has not been infected. As I said, we weren't aware of AIDS, then, or how it is spread.
Really?
Yes.
Andrew wipes sweat from his forehead.
You've testified the lesions on your face were visible to the people you worked with, correct?
That's right.
And it's your contention, that when the partners were made aware of the lesions, they jumped to the conclusion you had AIDS and fired you.
Absolutely.
Do you have any lesions on your face at this time?
One. Here, in front of my ear.
An ASSISTANT hands Conine a shaving mirror. She holds it before Andrew.
Remembering you are under oath, answering truthfully, can you see the lesion on your face, in this mirror, three feet away? Answering truthfully.
Andrew looks in the mirror: the lesion is NOT very visibl
By the time I was fired, there were four lesions on my face, much bigger...
Answer the question, please.
No. I can't really see it.
Thank you.
Andrew rubs his eyes.
(far away) This would be a good time to break for the day...
(far away) Your Honor? May I have ten minutes in re-direct?
(far away) Beckett?
Andrew finds the Judge looking at him.
Can you go on for ten minutes?
Yes sir.
Joe JUMPS UP from the plaintiff's table.
I only need five! (to Belinda, reaching for the mirror) May I?
Joe approaches Andrew, with the mirror.
Do you have any lesions on
any part of your body, at this time, that resemble the lesions that were on your face at the time you were fired?
Yes. On my torso.
If it please the court, I'd like to ask Mr. Beckett to remove his shirt, so that the jury can have an
accurate idea of what we're talking about.
We object, Your Honor. It would unfairly influence the jury.
Your Honor, if Mr. Beckett was forced by his illness to use a wheelchair, would the defense ask him to park it outside? We're talking about AIDS, we're talking about lesions. Let's
see what we're talking about. ANGLE ON MEMBERS OF THE JURY -- LOOKING APPREHENSIVE.
(a moment, then) I'll allow it. Would you mind removing your shirt, Mr. Beckett?
Allright.

The COURTROOM TURNS SILENT. Andrew removes his suit jacket. He's weak, so the smalles gesture requires effort. ANGLE ON BOB SEIDMAN -- WATCHING. Andrew undoes his tie. ANGLE ON THE MARINE JUROR -- WATCHING. Andrew unbuttons his collar buttons, working his way down ANGLE ON SARAH BECKETT -- WATCHING. Andrew stands, pulling his shirttails out of his trousers ANGLE ON CHARLES WHEELER -- WATCHING. Andrew removes his shirt -- THERE ARE PURPLE BLOTCHES SPLAYED ACROSS HIS CHEST AND ABDOMEN AND ARMS. The SCHOOLTEACHER JUROR GASPS. Sarah Beckett is silently crying. The LESBIAN JUROR closes her eyes.
Can you see the lesions on your chest in this mirror?
Yes.
Thank you.

head_text.subj: CAMERA MOVES IN ON CHARLES WHEELER...

text: Charles Wheeler strides down the corridor, flanked by Kenton, Killcoyne and Belinda, discussing strategy. Bob Seidman steps to Wheeler's side, keeping pace.
I've discovered something interesting, Charles.
(to Belinda) ... keep them from that area, on grounds of relevancy. (to Seidman) What, Bob?
No matter how hard I try, I can't lose a file in my computer.
NOW he's got EVERYONE'S attention.
The system automatically makes a backup.
Belinda holds up both hands, interrupting with:
I don't think I should hear this.
She walks away, giving a glance over her shoulder as:
You can erase the backup... (a challenge to Wheeler) But
why would you?
(venomous) What's the point, Bob?
(calm) Very interesting, Bob. Let's make a note of that. Andy didn't lose the complaint in his computer. He never put it in. He lied about that, too.
(weary) Charles...
If you feel differently, Bob, you should say so, when you're called to the stand. After all, this isn't a conspiracy.
Wheeler and the gang moves on, leaving Seidman alone in t high-ceilinged corridor. Belinda hesitates, before re-grouping with Wheeler and th rest, casting a curious glance toward Bob Seidman.

head_text.subj: CAMERA PULLS BACK FROM CHARLES WHEELER

text: Why did you recruit Andrew Beckett to your firm?
Andrew uses all his strength to concentrate. Charles Wheeler speaks with great sincerity.

If you're the owner of a major league ball club, you recruit the hot rookie. And Andy was tremendously promising as a young attorney. That's why we went after him, that's why we hired him, and that's why we stuck with him, year after year... waiting for the promise to be fulfilled. But it never was.
You kept giving him another chance?

Of course we did. When you've groomed someone they way we groomed Andy, nurturing him, lavishing all kinds of special treatment on him... you've made quite an investment. We were waiting for his promise to kick in, and deliver. But, ultimately, we could no longer ignore the gap between the promise and the reality... This is one of the saddest times in my life. To sit in this court, testifying to Andy's ultimate failure to make the grade. To discover that he is one of those people who wants to benefit by the system, but doesn't want to play by the system's rules. To think you
know someone, only to find out... you don't know them at all. It's heartbreaking.
Thank you. That's all for now, Your Honor.
Mr. Miller?
Joe rises. Adjusts his jacket. Wheeler waits.
(very gentle) Explain to me, if you can, Mr. Wheeler, explain this to me like I'm a ten year-old. This trial is not about a disease, is that what you're saying?

Not about your understandable, if unfounded, fear of catching AIDS through casual contact with someone who has it? You're saying, this trial is about Andrew Beckett's character. Am I getting this right?
Yes, character. To the extent that it affects a person's ability to do a great job.
Andrew looks away -- face shiny with sweat, breathing difficult. He takes in the rest of the court, while Wheeler's words THROB THROUGH THE AIR...
Andy worked when he wanted to work, telling us what he thought we needed to know about his lifestyle...
ANDREW'S POV -- ON RACHEL, sitting among the spectators. begins speaking, her WORDS OVERLAPPING Wheeler's (we shou the feeling she's giving her testimony).
I didn't mind covering for Andy, but I did wonder... when was he planning to deal with his problem?
Andrew blinks... what's going on? Looking back to the court: Joe presses in on Wheeler. Everything seems normal.
Sometimes it seems like society is
run by these kinds of people.
What kind of people?
People who want to bend the rules...
ANDREW'S POV -- KENNETH KILLCOYNE at the defense table:
If you want to be a leader in this society, you have to make certain sacrifices.
Wheeler keeps speaking:
... to suit their personal desires, and the rest of us have to live with it.
You have to make a decision: is this guy partner material?
Who makes the rules, Mr. Wheeler?
You?
Yes, I did see the lesions. I suspected he was sick...
CLOSE ON ANDREW: closing his eyes.

head_text.subj: THE VOICES GET LOUDER, FIGHTING WITH EACH OTHER

text: The everyday, common person with decent values...
It seems like he wasn't willing to face the
reality of his situation... Andrew slowly rises, the VOICES GETTING LOUDER:
I didn't tell the others, I was afraid to...
... But now, we're standing up for ourselves...
... But we shouldn't have fired him...
... It's time to get this society back on track!

Andrew OPENS HIS EYES... WE SWITCH TO HIS POV: The Judge, the Jury -- everyone silent, looking concerned ANDREW'S POV of the courtroom floor. Andrew falls into his own POV SHOT. In slow motion. He lies on the floor, looking up. ANDREW'S POV -- Joe steps over him.
Could you call an ambulance, please?

head_text.subj: A CRISIS IN A HOSPITAL ROOM, (INT./DAY)

text: working frenetically, trying to intubate Andrew, who IS HAVING SERIOUS TROUBLE BREATHING, his body HEAVING. The tube they're trying to put in place seems to be making matters worse. Miguel stands to the side, furious:
It's making it worse. Take it out. Take it out!

Dr. Gillman RUSHES into the room, in street clothes, obviously having answered an emergency call. She tries assessing the situation, just as the tube is removed and Andrew GASPS for breath. A NURSE places an oxygen mask ov Andrew's face and he drinks in the air. His eyes are wide open with fear, sweat covering his face.

head_text.subj: PHILADELPHIA CITY HALL, A BUSINESS DAY, (EXT./DAY)

text: TITLE: "Two weeks later."
If he was "mediocre," why did they gave him this major assignment
three weeks before they fired him?
They were testing him.

head_text.subj: JURORS SITTING AROUND A LONG TABLE IN A ROOM WITH TALL,

text: grimy windows (INT./DAY) ...
Jury deliberations.
They wanted to see if he'd rise to the challenge.
An American flag hangs on the wall.
They wanted to give him a final chance.
Makes sense.
I'd still love to know what happened to that missing file.
Wouldn't we all?
Ask the computer.
They say he wasn't competent. But, you heard him on the stand.
He sounded pretty smart to me.
Why would they fire him? Why not a medical leave, or...
They freaked out over the AIDS.
They hate homosexuals.
It's not against the law to disapprove of homosexuals.
It
is against the law to fire someone for having AIDS. That's why we're here.
You're the foreman. You haven't said anything. What do you think?
ANGLE ON -- THE MARINE, sitting at the head of the table.

head_text.subj: CAMERA MOVES IN SLOWLY ON HIM

text: They're saying he wasn't a good lawyer. He was mediocre. And the fact that they gave him the most important lawsuit they'd ever had, for one of their most important clients... they say that doesn't prove anything, because that was just a test. What did they call it? A carrot. To see if he'd rise to the occasion... Okay... Say I've got to send a pilot into enemy territory, and he's gonna be flying a plane that cost 350 million dollars... Who am I going to put into that plane? A rookie who can't cut the grade, because I want to see if he'll rise to the challenge? Or am I going to give that assignment to my best pilot, my most experienced, my sharpest, my top gun... The very best I've got?
Could somebody please explain that to me... like I'm a six year old?

head_text.subj: HOLD ON THE MARINE, AS THE JUDGE'S VOICE FADES IN

text: Members of the jury, have you reached a verdict?

Joe is utterly cool. Sitting beside  Andrew's empty chair . Among the spectators, Andrew's siblings, Jill, Matt, Rand his parents, Bud and Sarah... Rachel, Anthea and Miguel's sister Maria. The Marine rises to his feet.
We have, Your Honor...
Charles Wheeler looks the Marine in the eye.
We find for the plaintiff, Andrew Beckett.
Joe smiles, just barely, remaining calm. Charles Wheeler whispers to Belinda Conine.
Have you awarded any damages?
Yes, we have, Your Honor. (referring to a list) For back pay and loss of benefits ... one hundred fortythree thousand dollars.
Joe shakes his head, disappointed, writing down the amoun Wheeler and his crew SMILE -- THIS IS
For damages related to mental anguish and humiliation... we give no award.
Joe is  extremely disappointed.
And punitive damages we award... Four million, eight hundred and eighty two thousand dollars.

Joe throws his pen over his shoulder. COURTROOM BURSTS INTO AN UPROAR. Andrew's supporters, Joe's colleagues from his office rus forward, pounding him on the back. Andrew's family member hug each other...

head_text.subj: CEILING AS THE SOUNDS OF THE CROWD FADE...
OPERA MUSIC FADES IN, TAKING US TO...
ELEVATOR DOORS OPENING... JOE STEPPING INTO THE CORRIDOR

text: a hospital (INT./NIGHT), carrying two shopping bags from Famous 4th Street deli... Joe moves down the corridor, looking for a particular roo Dr. Gillman stands outside a hospital room, talking in a voice to Bud and Sarah Beckett. As Joe passes them, entering Andrew's room, he hears:
... if he comes out of the hospital this time, you mustn't expect him to be like he was before...

Joe steps into... ANDREW'S HOSPITAL ROOM (INT./NIGHT) ... A hand-painted banner is strung over Andrew's bed: "Victory." OPERA MUSIC plays on a portable CD player. ANDREW lies in hospital bed, with a pressurized oxygen mask on his face. JILL sits on the edge of Andrew's bed, holding his hand, smiling, speaking to Andrew in low tones. With his free hand, Andrew gently strokes Jill's forearm. (Andrew has a amazing assortment of tubes and IVs running into various parts of his body.) Andrew's brothers MATT and RANDY are sipping beers with R JIM, MIGUEL, Miguel's sister MARIA, Bruno and Chandra, wh Matt does a dramatic re-creation of the Marine Juror rend the judgment. Matt's audience is loving it. As Joe comes into the room, Jill rises to take the shoppi from him. Joe exchanges nods and greetings with the other People KEEP THEIR VOICES LOW, but there's a certain energ happiness evident in the room. ON ANDREW: Watching his friends and relatives with sparkl eyes and a weak, but grateful and peaceful smile. ON JOE: Glancing across the room, catching Andrew's look. Andrew smiles at Joe and pats his hospital bed, indicatin wants Joe to sit there. Joe crosses the room, sits on the edge of the bed. With some difficulty, Andrew removes his oxygen mask. His voice is raspy, weak:
What do you call a thousand lawyers chained together at the bottom of the ocean?
What?
A good start.
Joe smiles.
Excellent work, Joe. I thank you.
It was good working with you, Andrew. You're welcome. (sees the oxygen mask) Hey. Shouldn't you put that thing back on?
Andrew begins fitting the mask back in place, but his han weak. Joe helps adjust the straps behind Andrew's ears.
I better get home. Lisa and I are having some friends over.
(muffled by the mask) Sure thing.
Joe stands.
I'll see you, Beckett.
Andrew nods, weakly. But he's still smiling and his eyes are dancing.
(through mask) Thanks for coming by.
You bet. We'll see you later.
Joe heads for the door, meeting Miguel there.
(to Miguel) He's looking good. I wouldn't be surprised if he gets out of here soon.
We just want to get him home. Thanks for stopping by, Joe.
Miguel puts his arms around Joe and hugs him. Joe slaps Miguel's back.
Night.
Joe leaves. Miguel begins circulating among the "guests," saying:
He's tired. He ought to sleep.

head_text.subj: JOE STEPPING INTO THE HOSPITAL ELEVATOR, (INT./NIGHT)

text: saying to a GROUP OF DOCTORS and NURSES:
What do you call a thousand lawyers chained together at the bottom of the ocean?
The elevator doors close.
Matt gives Andrew's hand a squeeze, before leaving.
Night, Andy. See you tomorrow, buddy.
Rev. Jim pats Andrew's shoulder.
God bless you, Andy.
Bud Beckett kisses Andrew on the cheek.
Goodnight, son. Get some rest, okay?
Sarah Beckett is strong, kissing Andrew on the forehead.
Goodnight angel, my sweet boy...
Randy Beckett loses control of his emotions as he bends t his brother. He begins to sob.
Andy.
Andrew puts his weak arms, with the IV lines connected, around his brother Randy, to comfort him.
(through mask) I'm okay, bro. I'll see you tomorrow.

Jill hugs Andrew, giving Miguel a kiss as she leaves the Maria waves goodnight from the doorway, closing the door. Miguel sits on the edge of the bed, kicking off his shoes Miguel stretches onto the bed next to Andrew, picks up th remote control, and TURNS ON THE TV. Andrew pulls aside the oxygen mask, to say:
I'm ready...
Ready for what, baby?
Whatever.
I hope you're ready for "Studs," because that's what's on.
Andrew replaces the oxygen mask. They lie next to each other, watching television.
From inside the house: the phone rings.

head_text.subj: JOE AND LISA'S DARK BEDROOM, QUIET, (INT./NIGHT)

text: Lisa is sitting up in bed, having answered the phone. Joe is just waking up.
(to Joe) It's Miguel.
Joe sits bolt upright.
Miguel?
A TAXI ARRIVES and an elegant, well-dressed older COUPLE step out.

head_text.subj: RACHEL OPENS THE DOOR OF THE LOFT, FINDING MIGUEL'S FAMIL

text: on the other side: very dignified, handsome people who ha just arrived from Spain. They enter the apartment, where. A wake is in progress. Lots of food. People sharing stori about Andrew. Some people laughing. one or two softly cry as they hug each other. Someone has set up a "memento" table, with pictures of An at various stages of his life, and things that meant some to him, like programs from the opera, a ballcap, photos o favorite cat, etc. THEME MUSIC PLAYS, but we hear BITS OF DIALOGUE under the music ("You're Miguel's parents?" "Do you remember when Andy..." "I went to college with Andy..." etc.) Bud Beckett sits alone, very quiet. Miguel leads his parents over to Bud. Bud looks up, rises extending his hand to MIGUEL'S DAD. Miguel's father shake head in sadness, reaches for Bud and pulls him into his a an embrace.

head_text.subj: CAMERA MOVES THROUGH THE CROWD, SEEMING TO SEARCH FOR

text: CAMERA ZEROS IN ON THE TV SET, across the room, where BLA WHITE IMAGES ARE FLICKERING, ignored by everyone... AS CAMERA GETS CLOSER TO THE TV, it becomes apparent that images are BLACK AND WHITE HOME MOVIES, converted to vide THE HOME MOVIES FEATURE a bright-eyed LITTLE BOY... Andrew... Riding a bike with training wheels... Swinging wildly at a wiffle ball...

head_text.subj: AS CAMERA TRACKS INTO THE TV, PARTY SOUNDS AND THEME MUSI

text: FADES... People are still talking, still laughing, still crying, but we CAN'T HEAR THEM ANY LONGER. Instead... We hear only the SOUNDTRACK from the HOME MOVIES... Andrew SHOUTING GLEEFULLY as he chases a new puppy... Andrew SQUEALING as he jumps into a tiny swimming pool... Andrew on a swing, going higher and higher... And laughing. FADE TO BLACK. ROLL END CREDITS. May we never find space so vast,  planets so cold, heart  and mind so empty  that we cannot fill them  with love and warmth...
